summary: Pitney Bowes Inc. (NYSE: PBI) has launched SendPro C Auto, a new addition to its SendPro series featuring high-speed auto-feed functionality. This technology aims to automate mail processing, handle large mail volumes, print labels, ship parcels, and track shipments and costs, processing up to 120 letters per minute. It offers significant cost savings through postage discounts and increased efficiency, leveraging IoT and data analytics.

title: MTBC Acquires Cloud-based EHR Platform CareCloud - Healthcare M&A
summary: MTBC, a provider of cloud-based healthcare IT and revenue cycle management solutions, announced the acquisition of CareCloud, a cloud-based practice management EHR platform. This acquisition aims to accelerate MTBC's strategic roadmap by integrating CareCloud's advanced technology and expanding its network of healthcare providers. The deal was completed on a cash-free, debt-free basis and is expected to drive growth and operational efficiencies for the combined entities.

title: After its strongest year in a decade, Apple stock is historically expensive on a price-to-earnings basis
summary: Apple's stock concluded its strongest year in a decade with its price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio reaching a historic high of 24.7, up from just over 13 at the beginning of 2019. This elevated P/E ratio makes Apple historically expensive compared to its past performance, although it remains below the average for the S&P 500 information technology index and many other megacap tech stocks. Factors like improved iPhone 11 expectations, anticipation of the 5G 2020 iPhone cycle, and strong wearable device performance have contributed to the increased valuation, according to Deutsche Bank analyst Jeriel Ong.

title: Opinion: Bold stock-market calls for 2020: Begin with GE and Google
summary: This article presents bold stock-market predictions for 2020, focusing on companies like GE and Google. It reflects on the surprising performance of the S&P 500 in 2019, which surged 27% despite trade-war concerns and interest-rate uncertainty, making it the second-best showing since 2003. The author sets the stage for investment strategy discussions for the upcoming year.

title: Spotify to suspend political advertising in 2020
summary: Spotify Technology SA announced it would pause selling political advertisements on its music streaming platform in early 2020, including on its original and exclusive podcasts. This decision comes as campaigns for the U.S. presidential election intensify and other online platforms face pressure over misinformation and political ads, with Spotify citing a lack of robustness in its current systems to responsibly validate and review such content. The new policy will cover various political groups and content advocating for legislative and judicial outcomes, though it only applies to Spotify's ad sales, not embedded third-party content.

title: How to Invest in Esports - 10 Esports Stocks to Know
summary: This article provides an in-depth guide on investing in the rapidly growing esports industry, identifying four primary types of public companies for investment: games, media, hardware, and broad-based. It highlights specific companies within these categories like Activision Blizzard, Electronic Arts, Huya, Douyu, Modern Times Group, and Enthusiast Gaming, detailing their market capitalization, key assets, and contributions to the esports ecosystem. The piece underscores the mainstream emergence of esports viewership and the ongoing search for effective monetization channels within the industry.

title: Bilibili looks beyond anime to mainstream entertainment
summary: Bilibili is actively expanding beyond its traditional anime, comic, and games (ACG) content to establish itself as a mainstream entertainment platform. This expansion includes securing exclusive streaming rights for a major e-sports event and planning a large-scale New Year's Eve show, aiming to reach a market capitalization of $10 billion. The company is also building its content ecosystem through initiatives like paid courses and supporting music content creators.

title: Johnson & Johnson Announces Agreement to Acquire Remaining Stake in Verb Surgical Inc.
summary: Johnson & Johnson announced an agreement to acquire the remaining stake in Verb Surgical Inc., augmenting its digital surgery portfolio. This acquisition, following a successful collaboration with Verily, aims to make medical interventions smarter, less invasive, and more personalized by combining robotics, data science, and advanced instrumentation. The transaction is expected to close in the first half of 2020, enhancing J&J's leadership in the medical devices sector.

title: A new ad-tech merger takes aim at Google and Facebook's dominance
summary: Public ad tech companies Telaria and Rubicon Project have agreed to merge to create a stronger presence in connected television advertising and offer an alternative to "walled gardens" like Google and Facebook. The stock-for-stock merger aims to form a major independent sell-side ad platform, with Telaria stockholders owning about 47.1% and Rubicon Project stockholders about 52.9% of the combined company. This move comes as Google and Facebook face antitrust scrutiny, allowing the merged entity to target the growing CTV market more effectively.

title: Amazon hits back at claims it’s abusing open-source software
summary: Amazon Web Services Inc. has responded to criticism that it "strip-mines" open-source software projects by repackaging them as paid services. While AWS claims to be giving customers what they want and contributing significantly to open-source projects, some critics argue this practice undermines the sustainability of open-source companies, forcing them to compete against the very software they developed. Analysts suggest open-source companies must innovate and offer managed versions of their products to succeed against large cloud providers.

title: Nvidia debuts new DRIVE AGX Orin platform for autonomous cars and robots
summary: Nvidia has launched its new DRIVE AGX Orin platform, designed to power AI systems in autonomous vehicles and robots. The platform features the Orin system-on-a-chip, boasting 17 billion transistors and capable of 200 trillion operations per second, making it seven times faster than its predecessor. Didi Chuxing is already utilizing the platform for its Level 4 autonomous driving development, and Nvidia is offering free access to its DRIVE deep neural networks to other transportation industry customers to encourage adoption.

title: Check Point finds flaw in WhatsApp that could allow group-chat crash
summary: Israeli cybersecurity firm Check Point Software Technologies Ltd. identified and helped fix a vulnerability in WhatsApp that could have allowed a malicious message to crash group chats for all members. Users would need to reinstall the app and delete the problematic group to regain access. WhatsApp has since fixed the flaw in version 2.19.58, and users are advised to update their app.

title: Intel Buys Israeli AI Chipmaker Habana Labs for $2 Billion
summary: Intel Corp. acquired Israeli AI chipmaker Habana Labs for approximately $2 billion to strengthen its position in the rapidly expanding artificial intelligence silicon market. This acquisition is part of Intel's strategy to make its offerings essential to major silicon buyers and compete against companies like Alphabet's Google and Amazon's AWS, which are increasingly designing their own chips for data centers. Habana Labs is expected to operate independently for the time being.

title: Google Cloud and Palo Alto Networks Expand Strategic Partnership
summary: Google Cloud and Palo Alto Networks announced an expanded strategic partnership to deliver new cybersecurity solutions. The collaboration focuses on enhancing security for multi-cloud environments with Anthos and improving threat detection capabilities by combining their respective intelligence services. Palo Alto Networks will also run several of its services, including Prisma Access and Cortex, on Google Cloud Platform to offer increased visibility and security analytics for customers.

title: Your complete guide to investing with a conscience, a $30 trillion market just getting started
summary: ESG investing, which considers environmental, social, and governance factors, grew to over $30 trillion in 2018 and is projected to reach $50 trillion in the next two decades. Once considered niche and potentially detrimental to returns, ESG strategies have proven to be market-beating and are gaining significant momentum as investors demand greater transparency and companies face consequences for not adapting. The article explores various ESG strategies, highlighting their growing popularity, market performance, and the factors driving this surge, particularly among younger generations and institutions.

title: Buy or Sell a Car via Mobile with the New eBay Motors App
summary: eBay Motors has launched an all-new, automotive-focused app for Apple iPhone and Android, designed to streamline the buying and selling of vehicles. The app leverages advanced technology, including AI and machine learning, to offer features like license plate scanning for automatic listing population and AI-powered image sorting, promising an elevated experience for both buyers and sellers. Users can now easily list a car in under five minutes, browse a vast inventory with personalized homepages, and utilize robust filters.

title: Why Facebook and Google Dropped Out of the Top 10 in Glassdoor’s Best Places to Work List
summary: Big tech companies like Facebook and Google have fallen out of the Top 10 in Glassdoor's annual "best places to work" rankings. This shift comes as both companies face increased criticism and internal employee dissent regarding various issues and executive decisions. HubSpot Inc. took the top spot, while Microsoft Corp. was one of the few big tech companies to improve its ranking.

title: Which groups earn the most at Intel? Company offers peek at pay data other tech firms won’t show
summary: Intel released compensation data for its U.S. employees from 2017 and 2018, revealing that white and Asian males were the highest earners in most occupation categories. The company, which is transparent about its diversity efforts, aims to encourage other tech firms to share similar data. This disclosure comes as the EEOC for the first time required companies to include pay data.

title: How Amazon created AWS and changed technology forever
summary: This article details how Amazon Web Services (AWS) originated from Amazon's internal need to scale its e-commerce operations beyond books. AWS established the cloud computing industry, transforming technology and becoming a multi-billion-dollar market leader. However, it now faces significant competition from Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud.

title: I became part of the alt-right at age 13, thanks to Reddit and Google
summary: An anonymous teenager recounts his brief involvement with the alt-right at age 13, driven by a search for validation on Reddit and influenced by Google's algorithms. He discusses how online platforms contributed to radicalization by feeding him biased content, and his eventual disillusionment after a pro-Trump rally revealed the incoherence of alt-right ideas in person. The author concludes by calling for tech companies to be held accountable for their role in facilitating the spread of destructive ideologies.

title: Qualcomm Introduces Snapdragon 865 Processor
summary: Qualcomm Technologies has introduced the Snapdragon 865 5G Mobile Platform, featuring the Snapdragon X55 5G Modem-RF System, offering peak speeds up to 7.5 Gbps and significant improvements in AI performance, imaging, and gaming. The new platform includes the 5th generation Qualcomm AI Engine, gigapixel-speed ISP for advanced photography and videography, and new Snapdragon Elite Gaming features. Devices utilizing the Snapdragon 865 are expected to be commercially available in the first quarter of 2020.

title: CEOs of Microsoft, Apple, Google and more urge Trump administration to stay in Paris climate deal
summary: 73 leaders from major companies like Microsoft, Apple, Google, and Tesla, alongside labor unions, signed a letter urging the Trump administration to remain in the Paris Agreement on climate change. They argue that staying in the agreement will strengthen U.S. competitiveness, create jobs, and foster innovation. This appeal comes after the Trump administration initiated withdrawal from the accord, with notable absences from the signatory list including Amazon's Jeff Bezos and Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg.

title: Microsoft Security—a Leader in 5 Gartner Magic Quadrants
summary: Microsoft Security has been recognized as a Leader in five Gartner Magic Quadrants across various security areas including Cloud Access Security Brokers (CASB), Access Management, Enterprise Information Archiving, Unified Endpoint Management (UEM) tools, and Endpoint Protection Platforms. This recognition highlights the breadth and depth of Microsoft's security offerings, emphasizing their integrated approach that works across different cloud environments and non-Microsoft solutions. The article details Microsoft's strengths in each of these five categories, showcasing their commitment to providing comprehensive and integrated security solutions.

title: “QTUM” ETF Capitalizes on the Field of Quantum Computing
summary: The Defiance Quantum ETF (NYSEArca: QTUM) provides investors with exposure to quantum computing and machine learning technologies. QTUM tracks the BlueStar Quantum Computing and Machine Learning Index, which includes companies involved in the research, development, and commercialization of quantum computing systems. The ETF offers a liquid, transparent, and low-cost way to invest in this disruptive technology, with an equal-weight methodology for its approximately 60 global stocks.

title: 'Long game' starting to pay off for logistics startup ProServ
summary: ProServ Logistics, founded by former C.H. Robinson employees Brian Johnson and Dave Buhl, is starting to see the payoff of their long-term strategy. Five years in, the logistics startup, which focuses on relationship-based freight brokering, reported a 20% increase in revenue and 11% increase in profits in the third quarter, with an ambitious forecast of $22 million in revenue for 2020. Despite venturing into a highly fragmented market, Johnson's personal financial growth from ProServ has now exceeded his earnings at his previous corporate job.

title: Booking Holdings CEO Glenn Fogel on outlook and competition from Google
summary: Booking Holdings CEO Glenn Fogel discusses the company's outlook and addresses the competition posed by Google's entry into the travel industry. The discussion took place at the Phocuswright Conference in Hollywood, Florida.

title: Sonos acquires privacy-conscious AI startup Snips for $37.5 million
summary: Sonos has acquired the AI startup Snips for $37.5 million, aiming to integrate Snips' privacy-conscious conversational AI into its products. This acquisition will bring Snips' machine learning engineers and technology, including open-source projects for embedded AI assistants, under Sonos. Snips' focus on on-device processing without an internet connection differentiates it from competitors like Alexa and Google Assistant.

title: Can All Online Harms Be Tackled Using the Same Regulatory Approach?
summary: This article examines the UK's proposal for regulating online harms and questions whether illegal and lawful harms can be addressed with the same approach. It analyzes four factors (clear legal definitions, tailored technology, known real-world impact, and business consequences) that have proven effective in tackling online child sexual abuse material (CSAM), an illegal harm, and considers their applicability to lawful but harmful content. The author suggests that regulators need to develop clearer definitions, appropriate technologies, evidence bases for real-world impact, and align commercial interests to effectively manage a broader range of online harms.

title: Google teams with Citigroup bank to offer checking accounts from 2020
summary: Google is partnering with Citigroup bank and credit unions to launch checking accounts under the codename "Cache" starting in 2020. This venture aims to offer banking services in the US, with Google emphasizing a partnership approach where financial and compliance activities are handled by the banks and credit unions. Despite potential privacy concerns, Google believes this collaborative method will be more sustainable and beneficial for increasing digital financial activities.

title: An ETF to Consider as Alphabet Shuts Down Self-Driving Car Project
summary: Alphabet's Waymo is relocating its Austin self-driving car operations to Detroit and Phoenix due to challenges in commercializing the technology. This move comes after Morgan Stanley cut Waymo's valuation by 40%. Despite these setbacks, investors can still tap into the self-driving and electric vehicle market through the iShares Self-Driving EV and Tech ETF (NYSEArca: IDRV).

title: Google starts construction on $600M data center in unlikely burgeoning tech hub of New Albany, Ohio
summary: Google has begun construction on a $600 million data center in New Albany, Ohio, marking its third major tech facility in the area. The project is expected to be completed by early 2021 and follows investments from Facebook and Amazon, turning central Ohio into a data center hub due to significant tax cuts and strong electrical infrastructure. New Albany offered Google a substantial incentive package, including property tax abatement and waived fees, while the state of Ohio also provides sales tax exemptions for data centers.

title: UPS Debuts Home Delivery of CVS Medicine by Drone
summary: UPS has expanded its drone delivery services beyond hospital campuses, completing its first revenue-generating home deliveries of prescription medicines from a CVS Health Corp. pharmacy in Cary, N.C. The company used autonomous drones monitored by remote pilots, lowering packages by a winch, and plans to further grow drone deliveries, especially in rural areas, to compete with rivals like Amazon and FedEx. UPS was the first company approved by the FAA for commercial drone flights under the broadest airline rules.

title: What is an Ovintiv? Encana’s name change smacks of desperation
summary: Encana Corp.'s decision to change its name to Ovintiv Inc. is viewed as a desperate move by the author, who questions the efficacy of name changes in influencing stock performance. The article suggests that such changes often occur when companies are under pressure or struggling, and historically have not led to sustained improvements in share prices. It further implies that the name change, coupled with a move to the U.S., might be a cosmetic attempt to mask deeper business issues.

title: Marin Software Research Finds Significant Growth in eCommerce Spend
summary: Marin Software's Q3 2019 Digital Advertising Benchmark Report reveals significant growth in eCommerce spend, primarily driven by Amazon Advertising and seasonal events like Prime Day, with a 115% year-over-year increase. Mobile search continues to dominate, accounting for nearly half of total search spend, indicating a shift towards localized mobile queries. The report highlights opportunities for marketers to optimize campaigns across various platforms, including non-eCommerce features like Instagram Explore Feed and Facebook Watch, as the industry enters a busy Q4 season.

title: Yext aims to end the spread of fake news about brands
summary: Yext launched its first ad campaign, in partnership with TBWA\Chiat\Day New York, to combat the spread of misinformation about brands online. The campaign introduces a fictional character, "The Man Without the Answers," to highlight the dangers of false information. Yext's platform helps businesses control their online information and deliver verified facts to consumers across major search networks.

title: Apple Revamping Smart Home Efforts After Falling Behind Amazon, Google
summary: Apple Inc. is increasing hiring for a team dedicated to developing new smart-home software and devices to compete with Google and Amazon.com Inc. This initiative aims to expand Apple's smart-home platform, encourage more third-party accessory integration with the iPhone and Siri, and explore new home device possibilities beyond the HomePod speaker.

title: Future of Streaming Entertainment Starts Today with Launch of NVIDIA SHIELD TV, Starting at $149
summary: NVIDIA has launched its next generation of SHIELD TV, starting at $149, comprising two new models: SHIELD TV and SHIELD TV Pro. These devices feature the new Tegra X1+ processor, delivering 25% more performance, and support Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos for enhanced visual and audio experiences. The new SHIELD models also utilize AI upscaling for HD content to 4K resolution and offer access to a wide range of streaming, gaming, and AI capabilities.

title: HP Takes Printers Into the Cloud With Workpath, Command Center
summary: HP Inc. is introducing HP Workpath and HP Command Center to bring its multifunction printers into the cloud era, offering new revenue streams and customer loyalty opportunities for channel partners. Workpath enables app development for printers to simplify business processes, while Command Center provides cloud-based management and enhanced security for MFPs. These innovations aim to reduce labor for IT, improve security posture, and create new service offerings for partners like ImageNet Consulting.

title: Fertility benefits company Progyny starts strong after IPO
summary: Progyny, a Manhattan fertility benefits management company, saw its shares surge on its first day of trading on Nasdaq after an IPO that raised about $82 million. The company aims to address limited fertility benefits offered by employers and considers its profitability and public listing a way to elevate its stature in the industry. Progyny covers 1.4 million members across approximately 80 employers and reported $4 million in net income and $103.4 million in revenue in the first six months of the year.

title: How Amazon.com moved into the business of U.S. elections
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) has significantly expanded its presence in the U.S. election technology sector since 2016, with over 40 states using its services for various election-related functions and both major political parties relying on its cloud. While offering secure and cost-effective solutions for election administrators, this centralization raises concerns among security experts about potential vulnerabilities and the impact of a single major breach. Amazon maintains its systems are reliable and faults in past data exposures were due to customer errors, even as it continues to face scrutiny over its growing influence.

title: The Merged Taboola-Outbrain Wants to Take on Facebook and Google
summary: Taboola and Outbrain have announced a merger agreement aiming to create a stronger alternative to advertising giants Facebook and Google. The combined entity will have over 2000 employees and projected revenues of $2 billion in 2019, with Taboola's CEO Adam Singolda leading the new company. Outbrain shareholders will receive a 30% stake and $250 million in cash.

title: Phishing attacks abusing appspot.com and web.app domains on Google Cloud
summary: Zscaler ThreatLabZ has identified a rise in phishing attacks leveraging Google’s Appspot.com and Web.app domains. These sophisticated campaigns utilize SSL certificates from Google and employ well-designed login pages to spoof brands like Dropbox, Microsoft, and DocuSign, aiming to steal user credentials. The attackers use evasion techniques, including external JavaScript files, to bypass detection by analysis engines.

title: McDonald’s uses Alexa and Google to help with hiring
summary: McDonald's is implementing a new voice-activated job application system using Amazon's Alexa and Google Assistant to streamline hiring. This initiative, dubbed McDonald’s Apply Thru, allows job seekers to start applications through voice commands and is part of a broader technology push by the company to attract employees in a tight job market. The feature is available in multiple countries and aims to help McDonald's fill constant staffing needs across its 38,000 restaurants worldwide.

title: Introducing Movado Connect 2.0 - Powered with Wear OS by Google
summary: Movado announced its new Movado Connect 2.0 smartwatch collection, powered by Wear OS by Google. This next-generation timepiece features an innovative design with cutting-edge technology, available in 15 styles for women and men and two sizes (40mm + 42mm). The smartwatches, starting at $495, boast customizable dials, interchangeable straps, and a suite of features including activity tracking, GPS, heart rate monitor, and NFC payments with Google Pay.

title: Drone Deliveries Coming Soon, as Wing Unveils Plans for First-of-its-Kind Trial with FedEx and Walgreens
summary: Wing Aviation LLC, an Alphabet company, is collaborating with FedEx Express and Walgreens to launch a first-of-its-kind drone delivery service in Christiansburg, Virginia, next month. This pilot program, part of the U.S. DOT's Unmanned Aircraft System Integration Pilot Program, aims to enhance last-mile delivery, improve access to health care products, and create new growth avenues for local businesses. FedEx customers and Walgreens customers within designated zones will be able to receive packages and over-the-counter medicines via drone.

title: You might have never heard of America's top-paying company
summary: Palo Alto Networks, a cybersecurity company, has been identified as America's highest-paying company in Glassdoor's latest ranking, offering a median total pay of nearly $171,000 annually. This figure surpasses well-known tech giants like Facebook, Google, and Microsoft. The company's focus on a growing industry—cybersecurity and cloud services—contributes to its high demand for talent and generous compensation.

title: General Motors vs. Tesla: Software Engineer Pay
summary: This article compares software engineer salaries at General Motors and Tesla, highlighting the significant pay gap. It discusses the competitive landscape for autonomous driving talent and notes that tech companies like Facebook, Amazon, and Google offer substantially higher compensation packages, posing a challenge for traditional auto manufacturers like GM in attracting top talent. The piece underscores the "talent war" in the autonomous vehicle space and the necessity of high compensation to secure skilled engineers.

title: Better battery, Night mode, 'slofies' and other cool things coming to Apple's new iPhones
summary: Apple unveiled new iPhones, Apple Watch, and services, focusing on improved battery life, camera features like Night mode and "slofies," and an always-on display for the Apple Watch Series 5. The article details five key announcements, including new gaming and video subscription services that are affordably priced.

title: Bitfarms announces first delivery in growth expansion plan, adding 205 PH/s of new computing power
summary: Bitfarms announces the first delivery of 4,100 new generation miners for Phase 1 of its Sherbrooke computing center, expected to add approximately 205 PH/s of Bitcoin-focused computing power. This expansion will increase the company's total computing power to ~525 PH/s and improve operational efficiency. The T3 miners, manufactured by Innosilicon Technology Ltd., will utilize green surplus energy and are not subject to recent tariffs on Chinese goods.

title: Technology firms vie for billions in data-analytics contracts
summary: The article discusses the booming data-analytics market, highlighting companies like C3.ai and Databricks that are vying for billions in contracts. It details the journey of C3.ai's founder, Tom Siebel, and the industry's potential to revolutionize business productivity, despite current challenges in implementing truly sophisticated AI platforms. The piece also notes the significant financial valuations and growth projections for the data analytics sector.

title: Walgreens Boots Alliance nabs CIO from Kraft Heinz
summary: Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) has appointed Francesco Tinto as its new global chief information officer and senior vice president, effective September 6, 2019. Tinto, formerly the global CIO at Kraft Heinz Company, will lead WBA's global IT strategy during a period focused on digital transformation and cost reduction. His appointment comes as WBA aims to invest in digitalization capabilities and strengthen key partnerships, including a significant seven-year deal with Microsoft.

title: iRhythm unveils $13m Verily afib deal, readies $100m offering
summary: iRhythm Technologies announced a nearly $13 million deal with Alphabet's Verily to develop AI-based technology for atrial fibrillation screening, diagnosis, and management. Concurrently, iRhythm is preparing a $100 million stock offering to fund growth initiatives, including a significant portion for the Verily collaboration. The partnership aims to enhance cardiac care through data analytics and patient-centric solutions.

title: iRhythm, Verily Collaborate to Develop Atrial Fibrillation Detection Solution -
summary: iRhythm Technologies and Verily, an Alphabet company, are partnering to create health management solutions for atrial fibrillation (AFib) patients. The collaboration leverages iRhythm's AI-based arrhythmia diagnosis and Verily's health data analytics to address the underserved population at risk for asymptomatic AFib, with iRhythm making an initial payment of $5 million and potential milestone payments up to $12.75 million. This initiative aims to provide earlier warnings and improve the identification and management of AFib patients.

title: Google Stock Split History: What you Need to Know
summary: This article details the history of Google's stock splits, focusing on the creation of Class A, B, and C shares and their differing voting rights. It explains the reasons behind these splits, particularly how founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin maintained voting control. The article also discusses potential future stock splits and their implications for investors.

title: Outbrain Integrates with Google Display & Video 360 to Strengthen Programmatic Offerings
summary: Outbrain announced the full launch of its integration with Google's Demand-Side Platform, Display & Video 360, to enhance programmatic offerings. This partnership allows marketers to access Outbrain's premium native inventory at scale, enabling more efficient buying strategies. The collaboration is designed to provide consumers with higher quality ad experiences and expand Outbrain's programmatic solutions since its acquisition of Zemanta in 2017.

title: WPP forges closer links to big tech with launch of San Francisco campus
summary: WPP is opening a new campus in San Francisco to better serve major tech clients like Google, Facebook, and Amazon, and to foster collaboration between its agencies and tech platforms. This move is part of CEO Mark Read's three-year turnaround plan, aiming to transform WPP into a "creative transformation company" and address declining sales in key markets. The campus, which will house over 1000 people, is expected to be operational in the third quarter of 2021.

title: HPE Takes VMware Cloud Users On Its Synergy Journey To Greenlake
summary: HPE is expanding its GreenLake cloud-like IT consumption model by partnering with VMware to integrate GreenLake and HPE Synergy with VMware Cloud Foundation. This collaboration allows joint customers to run VMware Cloud Foundation as a service on GreenLake, offering a cloud-like experience with greater flexibility and cost efficiency in their own datacenters. The initiative is part of HPE's ambitious plan to deliver its entire portfolio as a service by 2022, leveraging GreenLake's metering and capacity management capabilities to optimize IT environments.

title: The age of disloyalty: most Singaporean shoppers open to new brands
summary: A new study reveals that brand loyalty is low among Singaporean shoppers, with 78% willing to consider new brands, especially for groceries and apparel. The Criteo S.A. Why We Buy survey found that consumers value good value and wide product selection over traditional loyalty programs. The study emphasizes that brands need to appeal beyond low prices and loyalty points by focusing on brand values and personalized online ads due to Singapore's high internet connectivity.

title: Apple apologises, and makes changes to Siri’s privacy policy
summary: Apple Inc. announced changes to its Siri privacy policy, stating it will no longer retain audio recordings for human review by default and will limit human review to employees only. This decision comes after a human review program raised privacy concerns. Users will now have the option to opt-in if they want their audio reviewed to improve the service.

title: BlackLine Partners with Google Cloud for Data Services
summary: BlackLine, Inc. has announced a collaboration with Google Cloud to enhance its financial automation platform with real-time, intelligent functionality, leveraging machine learning and artificial intelligence. This partnership supports BlackLine's global scaling and cloud-first strategy, aiming to improve customer experience and ensure secure financial data. The multi-year transition to Google Cloud is expected to begin in the Fall of 2019.

title: News Corp’s Knewz Aggregation Service Aims to Counter Facebook, Google
summary: News Corp is developing "Knewz," a news-aggregation app designed to counter Google and Facebook by presenting content without "bias" and spanning a wide range of sources. The company has long accused tech giants of profiting from its content without compensation and sees Knewz as a way to reward journalism provenance and drive traffic to publishers. Knewz will include content from diverse outlets and direct users to publishers' sites, reportedly without taking a cut of ad revenue.

title: Mystery new Sonos Move could be company’s first portable Bluetooth speaker
summary: Sonos is expected to launch its first portable Bluetooth speaker, named the Move, designed to work both within a home Wi-Fi network and as a standalone Bluetooth device. The speaker will feature Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, Apple AirPlay 2, and voice control via Amazon Alexa and Google Assistant, along with an Auto Trueplay feature for automatic sound tuning. It will be battery-powered with a charging dock and a USB-C port, marking a significant expansion for Sonos into portable audio.

title: New Wave Of Cisco Firings Sees 500 People Lose Jobs
summary: Cisco Systems Inc. has initiated a second round of layoffs in 2019, impacting 488 employees in California, primarily in engineering roles at its San Jose headquarters and Milpitas. These firings are part of Cisco's ongoing shift from a hardware manufacturer to a software developer. The company has experienced continuous layoffs under CEO Chuck Robbins, with previous cuts in 2017 and 2016.

title: TripAdvisor Plots Loyalty Program in Campaign Against Google
summary: TripAdvisor is reportedly considering implementing a loyalty program to boost user engagement and counteract reduced visibility due to Google. This strategy aims to incentivize current members to remain within the TripAdvisor ecosystem. The move is seen as a way for online travel agencies to differentiate themselves in the competitive travel booking market against Google Travel.

title: China start-up WeRide revs up self-driving ambitions with robotaxi JV
summary: Chinese smart automobility start-up WeRide has formed a joint venture with Baiyun Taxi Group and SCI (Guangzhou) Group to launch an autonomous cab service called WeRide RoboTaxi in Guangzhou. This move aims to accelerate its autonomous driving ambitions and help China catch up with US peers in Level 4 autonomous driving technologies. WeRide's CEO, Tony Han Xu, notes a 1-2 year gap between the US and China, primarily due to policy and regulation formulation.

title: Tesla has a huge incentive to deploy self-driving tech. But is the world ready?
summary: Tesla is aggressively pushing to deploy its Full Self-Driving (FSD) technology, driven by both Elon Musk's vision of a moral imperative and the financial incentive of unlocking hundreds of millions in deferred revenue. However, this aggressive timeline raises concerns among auto industry executives and safety advocates about premature deployment leading to accidents, damaging public trust, and confusing consumers about the technology's actual capabilities. The article questions whether Tesla's FSD is truly ready and highlights the lack of clarity surrounding its functionality and regulatory challenges.

title: IBM laid off up to 100,000 workers, Austin man's lawsuit claims
summary: An Austin man's lawsuit claims IBM laid off up to 100,000 workers in recent years, alleging age discrimination. Jonathan Langley, a 60-year-old former cloud salesman, contends he was forced out due to his age as IBM sought to rebrand as a "millennial-centric tech company." This lawsuit is one of several accusing IBM of firing older workers, with reports indicating significant reductions in its global workforce targeting older employees.

title: Fossil Group Launches Exclusive Smartwatch Capabilities within Wear OS by Google™ Platform - Multi-Day Battery Life and Tethered iPhone Calls
summary: Fossil Group announced new proprietary nextgen touchscreen smartwatch technology and an evolution in hybrid smartwatches within the Wear OS by Google platform. Key advancements include multi-day battery life through an exclusive app with four battery modes and the ability for iPhone users to make and receive calls on tethered smartwatches, thanks to a newly added speaker and proprietary app. These technological improvements, along with increased storage and memory, aim to enhance user experience and address critical customer demands for longer battery life and improved call functionality.

title: Artificial Intelligence at McKesson – AI Initiatives and Investments
summary: McKesson, a major pharmaceutical distributor, has been integrating AI solutions since 2012, emphasizing automation to free up human workers and transition to value-based care. The article details McKesson's investments in AI firms like Komodo Health, its adoption of Google Cloud for a flexible digital infrastructure, and its internal initiatives for automating white-collar tasks and finance management through partnerships with Genpact and the acquisition of Change Healthcare. These efforts aim to enhance diagnostics, streamline operations, and improve claims processing and reimbursement accuracy.

title: IBM fired at least 1,00,000 in recent years to appear 'cool' and 'trendy', lawsuit shows
summary: A former vice president of human resources for IBM testified in an age discrimination lawsuit that the company fired between 50,000 to 100,000 employees in recent years to appear "cool" and "trendy" to millennials, similar to Amazon and Google. This strategy involved targeting older workers through rolling layoffs to "correct" its seniority mix. IBM has faced several lawsuits regarding age discrimination and has seen a 19% reduction in its global workforce since 2013, coinciding with nearly seven years of shrinking revenue.

title: IBM fired as many as 1,00,000 employees in recent years to make itself look 'cool' and 'trendy', finds lawsuit
summary: IBM has reportedly fired as many as 100,000 employees in recent years to appear "cool" and "trendy" to millennials, according to a former vice president's deposition in an age discrimination lawsuit. The company, facing multiple lawsuits, aimed to shed its "old fuddy-duddy organization" image to better compete with companies like Amazon and Google. This strategy involved deliberately targeting older workers through rolling layoffs to "correct its seniority mix."

title: New study shows Facebook’s customer-satisfaction scores plunging
summary: A new study from the American Customer Satisfaction Index reveals a significant drop in Facebook's customer happiness, placing it near the bottom of surveyed industries. Privacy concerns were cited as the primary reason for dissatisfaction with the social media giant, whose score of 63 out of 100 is only slightly better than the cable TV industry. Despite this, other Facebook-owned platforms like Instagram maintain higher satisfaction scores.

title: Ex-Corporate Lawyer’s Idea: Rein In ‘Sociopaths’ in the Boardroom (Published 2019)
summary: Jamie Gamble, a retired corporate lawyer from Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, has concluded that corporate executives are "legally obligated to act like sociopaths." He argues that corporations are structured to care only about maximizing their own profits, viewing this as a "textbook case of antisocial personality disorder." Gamble's epiphany, which he developed while working on a novel, led him to write an essay about the "complex network of horribles" in corporate America.

title: Gartner Says Worldwide IaaS Public Cloud Services Market Grew 31.3% in 2018
summary: The worldwide Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) market experienced significant growth in 2018, increasing by 31.3% to reach $32.4 billion. Amazon maintained its position as the leading vendor, followed by Microsoft, Alibaba, Google, and IBM, indicating a consolidation trend favoring major providers who can invest heavily in scalable data center infrastructure and offer a rich feature set.

title: Apple Is Now the Most Valuable Brand Ever, Thanks to This 1 Thing. (The Good News Is You Can Totally Do It Too)
summary: Apple has become the most valuable brand globally, valued at $205 billion, largely due to its commitment to delighting customers beyond expectations. While the iPhone's success contributes, the core reason for its brand value lies in fostering positive feelings through every customer interaction. The article suggests that any business can achieve similar brand success by focusing on unexpected customer delight rather than just meeting expectations.

title: Tinder is the latest app to boycott Google Play by bypassing its payment system
summary: Tinder has joined a growing trend of apps bypassing Google Play's payment system to avoid the 30% revenue cut. The online dating site now forces users to enter credit card details directly into its app, removing the Google Play payment option for future purchases. This move could spark a domino effect among other app developers looking to reclaim more revenue from in-app transactions.

title: OpenText announces fresh partnerships and talks Google at Enterprise World
summary: OpenText announced expanded partnerships at its Enterprise World event, notably with Google Cloud, where OpenText will be the preferred partner for Enterprise Information Management Services (EIM). The company emphasized alignment with partners and a cloud-first strategy, while also maintaining support for on-premises deployments. OpenText also revealed a new partnership with Mastercard to offer spot financing to automotive clients.

title: Investors Use Indexes to Play in the Video Game Business (Published 2019)
summary: The video game industry, transitioning from arcades to mobile and streaming, presents significant investment opportunities. Big tech companies like Microsoft, Google, and Amazon are entering the streaming video game market, alongside equipment makers and game publishers set to capitalize on new capabilities. The industry is projected to reach $180 billion in annual sales, with investors increasingly using exchange-traded funds to gain exposure.

title: Cloud Volumes ONTAP: Experience the Benefits of ONTAP Across Azure, AWS, and GCP
summary: NetApp has expanded its Cloud Volumes ONTAP (CVO) offering to include Google Cloud Platform (GCP), making it available across all three major cloud providers: Microsoft Azure, Amazon AWS, and Google Cloud Platform. CVO offers full ONTAP features in the cloud, enabling use cases like multi-cloud disaster recovery, cost-efficient storage for cloud-native applications, and persistent storage for Docker and Kubernetes. The article differentiates CVO (IaaS, user-managed) from Cloud Volumes Service (CVS) (PaaS, fully managed).

title: Big tech company to move HQ from Sunnyvale to San Jose
summary: Rambus Inc. is relocating its headquarters from Sunnyvale to North San Jose, acquiring 90,000 square feet at 4453 North First St. The move is driven by the desire for a more modern workspace, lower lease costs, and proximity to employee housing, reflecting a broader trend of tech companies moving to San Jose as the Peninsula's commercial vacancy rates tighten. This shift highlights San Jose's growing appeal for tech companies, demonstrated by other recent moves like HPE and McAfee, and ongoing development in the area.

title: Spotify targets emerging markets with stripped-down app
authors: Lulu Yilun Chen and Lucas Shaw and Bloomberg
summary: Spotify has launched a stripped-down version of its music streaming app, Spotify Lite, targeting emerging markets in Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and Latin America. This move aims to boost growth outside its main strongholds, addressing limitations like data plans and slower networks, while also reassuring investors about its growth prospects amidst ongoing losses and significant royalty payments. The new app is designed to use less storage and data, mirroring strategies used by rivals like YouTube and Netflix.

title: Here is What You Need to Know About Douyu, Chinese Streaming Unicorn Eyeing US IPO
summary: Douyu, a leading Chinese game streaming unicorn backed by Tencent, is preparing for a US IPO with an expected valuation between $3.73 billion and $4.54 billion. The company reported a profitable Q1 2019, with revenues soaring 123.4% year-on-year and a significant increase in paying users to over 6 million, surpassing its rival Huya. Despite its success, concerns remain about Douyu's long-term growth and its reliance on user tips, differing significantly from Twitch's more diverse revenue streams.

title: Mark Shuttleworth sold a tech startup he built in his garage for $575 million and used the money to visit space
summary: Mark Shuttleworth, founder of Thawte, sold his tech startup for $575 million in 1999 and used $20 million to finance a trip to space in 2002. He later founded Canonical, an open-source software provider, which he fully funded himself. Shuttleworth details his journey from starting Thawte in his parents' garage to his space adventure and his vision for open source through Canonical.

title: Interview with Thomas M. Siebel on Digital Tranformation
summary: Thomas M. Siebel, Chairman and CEO of C3.ai, discusses his entrepreneurial journey from Oracle to Siebel Systems and now C3.ai, highlighting the impact of digital transformation driven by elastic cloud computing, big data, AI, and IoT. He shares insights on building a company culture, the potential negative impacts of AI, and the thesis of his book "Digital Transformation," urging business leaders to adapt to an existential shift in the corporate world. Siebel also touches on entrepreneurial philanthropy and offers advice to young professionals.

title: GIC to Fuel Equinix’s Hyperscale Market Ambition
summary: Equinix, the world’s largest data center provider, is partnering with GIC, Singapore’s sovereign wealth fund, in a $1 billion joint venture to build and operate hyperscale data centers for major digital platforms. This initiative, branded xScale, aims to address the growing demand from tech giants like Alibaba, Amazon, and Microsoft for large-scale data center capacity, especially in Europe. The move allows Equinix to expand into the hyperscale market without cannibalizing its core retail colocation business, leveraging GIC’s capital for significant investments.

title: Domino’s CEO Doesn’t Want a Robot Making Your Pizza
summary: Domino's CEO Ritch Allison believes pizza will endure, but acknowledges a high-tech shift in its creation and delivery. While the company is exploring innovations like driverless delivery and digital assistants for ordering, Allison expresses reservations about robots making pizzas. Domino's (DPZ) faces increasing competition from other delivery services in the quick-service restaurant industry.

title: JPMorgan Chase expands Seattle engineering center to 100 people, plans to add hundreds more
summary: JPMorgan Chase is significantly expanding its technology engineering center in Seattle, growing to 100 people in its first year and signing a new lease to accommodate hundreds more. This expansion is part of the financial services giant's major investment in cloud technology, partnering with AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud, and signals Seattle's growing potential as a fintech hub. The bank's CEO, Jamie Dimon, initially skeptical, is now fully committed to cloud adoption and integrating AI into operations.

title: Outbrain’s Digital Audience Reach Surpasses Facebook, Google & Others in Key Global Markets
summary: Outbrain announced it is the global leader in total digital reach for April, surpassing competitors like Facebook and Google in key markets including the U.S., Spain, Germany, and the UK. The company reported reaching 88% of the total digital population in the U.S. and experienced significant growth across Europe, attributing its success to consumers turning to the open web for discovery experiences. Outbrain highlights its platform as a strong alternative for advertisers seeking to diversify media spend and enhance audience engagement outside the closed web.

title: 12 Stocks To Buy For Market's Upturn: Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs has advised investors to view the recent stock market slump as a major buying opportunity, particularly focusing on companies with low labor costs, cyclicals, small caps, and value plays. The firm identified 25 buy-rated stocks that have fallen more than their historic correlations with the broader market, implying a faster recovery. They provided a list of 12 specific stocks, including McDonald's, Chevron, and Alphabet, that are positioned for an upturn.

title: Blockchain Could Make You—Not Equifax—the Owner of Your Data
summary: This article discusses how blockchain technology can empower individuals to own and monetize their personal data, challenging traditional data brokers like Equifax. It explains how blockchain-based solutions use cryptography, such as keys, hashes, and smart contracts, to create a decentralized system for data exchange, giving users control over who accesses and profits from their information. The piece also addresses the challenges of scalability and storage within blockchain technology but highlights its potential to disrupt the current data economy.

title: Tipalti Works Behind The Scenes To Ensure Creators On Twitch, Wattpad, Vimeo, And More Get Paid On Time
summary: Tipalti is a software company that processes payments for various platforms like Twitch, Vimeo, and Wattpad, ensuring creators get paid on time. The company's primary function is to strengthen the bond between platforms and creators by providing timely payments, including an early payment program to address cashflow issues. This service is crucial for creator loyalty and the growth of platforms in the $100 billion U.S. digital ad revenue ecosystem.

title: 10 Things You Didn’t Know About Rob Glaser
summary: This article provides 10 interesting facts about Rob Glaser, the founder of RealNetworks and a partner at Accel Partners. It covers aspects of his professional career, including his time at Microsoft and investments, as well as personal details regarding his net worth, charitable work, political support, and family life.

title: Work on Boston’s tallest office building in 25 years has started
summary: Construction has begun on One Congress, a 600-foot-tall skyscraper in Boston, set to become the city's tallest office building in 25 years. The building, scheduled to open in 2022, will serve as the new headquarters for State Street Corp., which has leased about half of its 1 million square feet. This project is part of a larger redevelopment of the Government Center Garage area and signifies continued growth in Boston's downtown job market.

title: Chip-Designer ARM Breaks Silence on Huawei Ties
summary: ARM Holdings PLC's president, Graham Budd, has addressed the company's relationship with Huawei following a U.S. export ban, indicating the company is evaluating its options and seeking solutions from policymakers. Despite being U.K.-headquartered, ARM acknowledged that U.S. sanctions impact its global operations and researcher base in the U.S. ARM's designs are critical for Huawei's chip development, including the Kirin series, and while ARM stated it would continue investing in China, it did not explicitly commit to continued work with Huawei.

title: Progressive's Tricia Griffith shines in Glassdoor's ranking of the country's best CEOs
summary: Progressive Corp. CEO Tricia Griffith has been ranked No. 61 on Glassdoor's list of the 100 best CEOs in America, with a 93% approval rating from employees. The article highlights employee praise for the company's work environment and benefits, balanced with complaints about long hours. It also touches on a boom in mortgage refinancing due to low rates and other local news involving the Cleveland Orchestra and Cleveland State University research.

title: Fluent acquires AdParlor, a social ad specialist previously owned by Adknowledge, for $10M
summary: Fluent, a marketing company, has acquired AdParlor, a social advertising specialist, for $10 million. AdParlor, originally a major Facebook Ads API vendor, was previously owned by AdKnowledge (now V2 Ventures). This acquisition aims to integrate AdParlor's social media advertising expertise across various platforms into Fluent's existing marketing technology stack.

title: HPE to offer entire portfolio as-a-Service by 2022
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) announced plans to transition its entire portfolio to an as-a-Service model by 2022, offering customers subscription-based, pay-per-use, and as-a-Service options while still providing traditional hardware and software. This strategy involves scaling HPE GreenLake, expanding into new market segments, and forming partnerships with companies like CyrusOne, Equinix, and Google Cloud, along with introducing new offerings for mid-market businesses and Network as-a-Service (NaaS) via Aruba. The move aims to provide customers with a consistent cloud experience, flexibility, and financial benefits, as evidenced by GreenLake's rapid growth and high renewal rates.

title: Simplify Data Management Across Public or Private Clouds with NetApp Cloud Volumes
summary: NetApp is enhancing data management across public and private clouds by offering a feature-rich portfolio of cloud data services. The article details NetApp's public cloud offerings like Azure NetApp Files, Cloud Volumes Service for Google Cloud and AWS, and Cloud Volumes ONTAP, alongside on-premises solutions such as NetApp HCI and Cloud Volumes Service On-Premises. These solutions aim to provide enterprise-class file services, high performance, and simplified data management, catering to various cloud strategies and regulatory requirements.

title: Adobe has an ambitious plan to help the public spot fake images
summary: Adobe is working with UC Berkeley scientists and DARPA to develop AI-powered software capable of detecting, analyzing, and reversing facial manipulation in images. The tool focuses on detecting alterations made with Photoshop's "liquify" warping tool, aiming to democratize image forensics in the face of increasingly sophisticated AI manipulation. While the technology is in early stages, the company acknowledged the urgent need for such tools as AI-driven visual manipulation becomes more seamless and harder to detect.

title: Ant Financial's Ability to Disrupt Could Boost EMQQ ETF
summary: The article discusses how Ant Financial's disruptive capabilities, particularly in fintech and now healthcare, could benefit the Emerging Markets Internet & Ecommerce ETF (EMQQ). EMQQ holds Alibaba Group, a majority stakeholder in Ant Financial, positioning the ETF to capitalize on Ant Financial's innovative strategies in emerging markets. The piece highlights the rapid growth in the financial technology space and Ant Financial's expansion into health insurance with its Ziang Hu Bao program, attracting millions of participants.

title: Tech titans fuel a scramble to build large-scale offices
summary: Tech giants like Google, Amazon, and Netflix are driving a massive scramble for office space in Los Angeles, leading to billions of dollars in new construction and radical redevelopments. These "content creators" prefer large-scale, campus-like facilities with unique amenities over traditional high-rise offices, focusing their hubs in areas like Hollywood, Culver City, and Playa Vista. This trend is sparking an economic boom and attracting a multiplier effect of smaller service providers looking to be near these major players.

title: South Korean firm Yanolja that reinvented love hotels gets Booking, GIC funding
summary: South Korean firm Yanolja, known for reinventing "love hotels" into modern budget accommodations, has secured $180 million in funding from Booking Holdings Inc and Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC Pte Ltd, pushing its valuation over $1 billion. CEO Kim Jong-yoon announced plans for an IPO as early as next year, aiming for global expansion, particularly in Southeast Asia, to compete with Oyo. The company's success highlights a shift in the accommodation market by targeting millennials and short-term tourists, moving past the stigma associated with traditional love hotels.

title: General Motors Competes With Google, Facebook Over Israeli Tech Workers, GM Exec Says
summary: General Motors is intensely competing with tech giants like Google, Facebook, and Apple for top engineering talent in Israel, according to Gil Golan, executive director of GM’s Advanced Technology Center in the country. GM's R&D center in Israel has grown significantly and plans further expansion, emphasizing the appeal of working on impactful autonomous vehicle technology. The article also highlights the growing presence of other major automakers like Ford, Renault, Nissan, Daimler AG, and Volkswagen Group in Israel, indicating the country's importance in autonomous vehicle R&D.

title: Salesforce bets on big data with $15.3 billion Tableau buy
summary: Salesforce.com Inc announced its acquisition of big data firm Tableau Software Inc for $15.3 billion in an all-stock deal, marking its largest acquisition to date. This move aims to enhance Salesforce's data insights offerings to clients and follows a trend of tech giants investing in big data analytics. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter, with Tableau operating independently, but will impact Salesforce's 2020 adjusted profit despite adding to revenue.

title: Salesforce is buying data visualization company Tableau for $15.7B in all-stock deal
summary: Salesforce announced its acquisition of data visualization company Tableau for $15.7 billion in an all-stock deal. This strategic move aims to enhance Salesforce's analytics capabilities and diversify beyond CRM software, following Google's recent acquisition of Looker. Tableau will operate independently, retaining its headquarters in Seattle and current leadership.

title: Amazon unveils a chopper-plane mashup to deliver packages
summary: Amazon unveiled a new drone design for its Prime Air fleet, a hybrid helicopter-plane mashup designed for package delivery. The drone features AI and takes off vertically before flying horizontally like a plane. Amazon aims to use these drones for test deliveries of household goods, with the goal of delivering packages within 7.5 miles of a warehouse within 30 minutes, handling items up to five pounds.

title: Stock Market Turns Lower; Google Shares Tank As U.S. Prepares Antitrust Probe
summary: The stock market, particularly the Nasdaq, turned lower on Monday, with Google-parent Alphabet's shares falling amid news of an impending antitrust probe by the U.S. Justice Department. Investors were also closely watching Apple stock ahead of its Worldwide Developers Conference.

title: Exclusive: Amazon interested in buying Boost from T-Mobile, Sprint - sources
summary: Amazon.com Inc is reportedly interested in acquiring Boost Mobile from T-Mobile US Inc and Sprint Corp, according to sources familiar with the matter. The potential deal would allow Amazon to utilize the new T-Mobile's wireless network for at least six years and could also include the divestment of wireless spectrum. This move comes as T-Mobile and Sprint look to sell assets like Boost to gain regulatory approval for their planned $26 billion merger.

title: Palo Alto Networks Introduces Prisma: The Secure Way to Cloud
summary: Palo Alto Networks announced Prisma, a new cloud security suite designed to provide simpler, more secure, and comprehensive cloud security. Prisma consolidates and expands on existing cloud security products, offering solutions for secure access, data protection, and application security across various cloud environments. With approximately 9,000 enterprise customers, Prisma aims to be the largest cloud security business globally.

title: Google to ARM: List of companies that severed ties with Huawei after US ban
summary: Following the US government's ban on Huawei due to national security concerns, a number of major technology companies have severed or suspended ties with the Chinese firm. This article lists companies including Google, ARM Holdings, Microsoft, Lumentum Holdings, Panasonic, Intel, Qualcomm, Xilinx, and Broadcom, as well as organizations like the Wi-Fi Alliance and SD Association, highlighting the significant impact of the ban on Huawei's global operations. The ban initially included a 90-day reprieve for existing products, but future uncertainty remains for Huawei's software and hardware capabilities.

title: Huawei: ARM memo tells staff to stop working with China’s tech giant
summary: UK-based chip designer ARM has instructed its staff to suspend all business with Huawei and its subsidiaries following the US trade clampdown, as its designs contain "US origin technology." This move is considered an "insurmountable" blow to Huawei's ability to develop its own chips for smartphones, 5G base stations, and computer servers. Huawei acknowledges the pressure on its partners due to politically motivated decisions but remains confident the situation can be resolved.

title: We learn more about Huawei's Google ban from memes than recent news reports
summary: Google is withdrawing the licensing of the Android Operating System to Huawei's devices, prompting panic amongst Huawei users despite a temporary reprieve. Huawei states it is prepared with stockpiled components, while the internet has reacted with an array of memes humorously theorizing about the implications of the ban. These memes reflect the market situation, the company's difficult period, and the timeline of events leading up to the blacklisting.

title: Verily Forms Strategic Alliances with Novartis, Otsuka, Pfizer and Sanofi to Transform Clinical Research
summary: Verily, an Alphabet company, has formed strategic alliances with pharmaceutical giants Novartis, Otsuka, Pfizer, and Sanofi to revolutionize clinical research. These collaborations aim to leverage Project Baseline's evidence generation platform to engage more patients and clinicians, streamline studies, and collect higher quality data, ultimately improving health outcomes and informing better treatments. The initiative seeks to make research more accessible and diverse.

title: Google, Qualcomm, Intel, and Broadcom all cut ties with Huawei
summary: Google revoked Huawei’s Android license, and American chipmakers like Intel, Qualcomm, and Broadcom announced they would stop selling components to the Chinese smartphone giant following a U.S. executive order banning American companies from supplying Huawei. This move is a major escalation in the U.S.-China trade war, potentially crippling Huawei's smartphone sales and delaying China's 5G network build. Analysts warn of potential retaliation from China against American tech companies operating within the country.

title: VICTOR COLEMAN
summary: Victor Coleman, Chief Executive, Founder, and Chairman of Hudson Pacific Properties, is noted for his company's high-profile tech and media projects, including Netflix's lease at the Epic tower and Google's future Los Angeles home at the redeveloped Westside Pavilion. His background includes co-founding Arden Realty Inc. and serving on the boards for the Ziman Center for Real Estate at UCLA and the Los Angeles Sports & Entertainment Commission. He is also an investor in the National Hockey League’s Las Vegas Golden Knights.

title: Microsoft, Sony partner on streaming games, chips and AI
summary: Microsoft and Sony have announced a strategic partnership where Sony will leverage Microsoft's cloud services, specifically Azure, for game and media streaming. The collaboration also extends to co-developing image sensors and integrating Microsoft's AI technology into Sony's consumer products. This deal aims to bolster Microsoft's cloud business and provide Sony's gaming platform with enhanced streaming capabilities, especially as its PlayStation 4 nears the end of its lifecycle.

title: Communication Services XLC ETF Closes Up 2.24%
summary: The Communication Services Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLC) closed up 2.24% on Wednesday, amidst a strong market performance and news of delayed automotive tariffs. The XLC ETF, composed of major communication services companies like Facebook, Google, and Netflix, represents a relatively new sector formed in late 2018. The sector's constituents include significant growth drivers, though some analysts express caution about potential over-regulation.

title: Communication Services XLC ETF Closes Up 2.24%
summary: The Communication Services Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLC) closed up 2.24% on Wednesday, driven by positive market news. The ETF, comprising major companies like Facebook, Google, and Netflix, tracks the Communication Services Select Sector Index, a relatively new sector formed in late 2018. Analysts, however, express some skepticism about the future of communications due to potential over-regulation.

title: Enabling digital success with APIs and Microservices
summary: This article discusses how APIs and microservices are crucial for digital success in modern organizations by enabling collaboration, innovation, and scalable, resilient systems. It highlights the challenges of legacy IT assets and provides an approach for successful API and microservices implementation based on five key pillars. The piece also explains the roles of APIs and microservices in driving better customer experiences and achieving zero-downtime service availability.

title: American Axle to fund $5M in small business subsidies in Campau/Banglatown
summary: American Axle & Manufacturing Holdings Inc. will fund $5 million to support subsidies for small businesses opening in the Campau/Banglatown neighborhood bordering Hamtramck, Detroit. This investment is part of a larger $35 million commitment to the city's Strategic Neighborhood Fund aimed at extending Detroit's revitalization into its neighborhoods. The funds will help make it economically feasible for businesses to establish themselves in the area, which is one of the fastest-growing neighborhoods in the city.

title: ACI Acquires Western Union’s Walletron Mobile Bill-Presentment Business
summary: ACI Worldwide Inc. has acquired Walletron Inc., Western Union's mobile bill-presentment business, in a move to enhance its electronic bill-payment offerings. This acquisition follows ACI's earlier $750 million cash acquisition of Western Union's Speedpay business, emphasizing ACI's strategy to bolster its position in the bill-payment market. Walletron's technology, which enables bill viewing and payments via mobile wallets like Apple Wallet and Google Pay, is used by over 6 million consumers globally.

title: Will Google ever buy Pinterest? The price tag (mostly) keeps going up
summary: This article discusses the ongoing speculation about whether Google will acquire Pinterest. It highlights how Pinterest's valuation has increased significantly since its early days, making an acquisition progressively more expensive for Google. The piece explores the idea of Pinterest as a search engine and its potential threat to Google, while also touching on Pinterest's IPO and its efforts to combat misinformation.

title: Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System, California, USA
summary: The Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System is a 392MW thermal solar power plant in the Mojave Desert, US, and is the world’s biggest solar thermal power tower system. Jointly owned by NRG Energy, Google, and Brightsource, the $2.2bn project began operations in December 2013, generating enough electricity for 140,000 Californian homes and offsetting more than 400,000 tons of CO2 annually. The plant utilizes Luz Power Tower 550 technology with a dry-cooling system to significantly reduce water consumption.

title: Yext CEO: New HQ, snugged between Google and Apple, will bring 500 jobs
summary: Yext's CEO announced a new headquarters, strategically located between Google and Apple offices, which is expected to create 500 jobs. The company's investment in the new building is projected to exceed $150 million over 12 years, covering rent and build-out costs.

title: Five fund buyers reveal their favourite tech ETFs
summary: This article compiles the favorite tech ETFs of five different fund buyers, highlighting various approaches to gaining tech exposure, including robotics and automation, pure-play sector exposure, and broad Nasdaq 100 coverage that includes FAANG stocks. Each fund buyer explains their rationale for choosing particular ETFs, considering factors like methodology, diversification, liquidity, and how well the ETF captures the evolving definition of "tech."

title: Alphabet earnings: Google juggles good investments with being a target for EU fines
summary: Alphabet (Google's parent company) has consistently beaten earnings expectations in 2018, primarily due to "paper profit" from investments rather than core business revenue. These strong reported earnings also occurred despite significant antitrust fines imposed by the European Union.

title: After years serving CEOs, Goldman's Ayco also wants other workers
summary: Goldman Sachs' Ayco unit, traditionally serving top executives, is expanding its financial advisory services to target millions of other affluent employees at major U.S. companies. This expansion, which includes offering high-yield savings accounts and personal loans through its Marcus online bank, is part of Goldman's strategy to reposition itself as a traditional bank and reach a wider customer base to meet its $5 billion new annual revenue target by 2020. Despite some investor concerns about entering new territory, Goldman views Ayco's growth into the mass affluent market as a cost-effective way to acquire new clients.

title: Here are the executive power moves that help explain everything that's going on in finance, tech and retail
summary: This article details significant executive appointments and promotions across finance, tech, and retail sectors. Key moves include JPMorgan appointing Jennifer Piepszak as CFO and Marianne Lake to CEO of Consumer Lending, Google Cloud hiring former SAP executive Robert Enslin, and Flexport onboarding a Chief Data Officer and Chief Information Security Officer. Best Buy also announced Corie Barry as its first female CEO, and Robinhood made changes to its compliance team, featuring Scott Friedman stepping down and John Castelly taking over as Chief Compliance Officer.

title: Who really controls a tech company once it goes public
summary: This article examines how tech company founders retain control after going public, often through dual-class share structures with "super-voting" shares. It highlights examples like Lyft, Pinterest, and Google, where founders maintain significant voting power despite owning a minority of shares. The piece also discusses institutional investors' pushback against these structures, leading to actions by market indexes and the inclusion of "sunset" provisions in some IPOs.

title: Detroit wins over Waymo for self-driving car plant
summary: Waymo, Google's self-driving affiliate, announced its decision to repurpose a former American Axle plant in Detroit for installing autonomous vehicle hardware and software into cars. This move signifies Detroit's growing importance in next-generation auto manufacturing, attracting an investment of nearly $14 million and potentially creating 400 jobs. The decision is seen as a major win for Detroit against Silicon Valley in the evolving automotive industry, emphasizing the region's engineering talent and manufacturing capabilities.

title: eBay's Managed Payments Offering Expands
summary: eBay is expanding its managed payments offering to Germany, making it the second market after the U.S., pending regulatory approval. This expansion aims to provide buyers with more payment flexibility and choice, while also giving sellers access to new customers and simplifying business processes with lower costs. The company has already processed $363M in GMV and saved sellers $2.7M through its managed payments as of Q1 2019.

title: NetApp Is Named 2018 Google Cloud Technology Partner of the Year for Infrastructure
summary: NetApp has been named the 2018 Google Cloud Technology Partner of the Year for Infrastructure, recognized for its achievements in helping customers build and run applications on Google Cloud. The NetApp® Cloud Volumes Service for Google Cloud Platform, jointly developed with Google Cloud, provides a fully-managed file storage service enabling customers to move workloads to Google Cloud faster and with higher performance. This award highlights the strong partnership between NetApp and Google Cloud in delivering innovative data services for hybrid cloud environments.

title: Snap has three years to make a profit before it runs out of money
summary: Snap, once valued at $24 billion upon its 2017 IPO, has just over three years to become profitable before it runs out of cash, according to a Financial Times analysis. Despite a struggling stock price, executive exodus, and a disastrous app redesign, the company is attempting a turnaround by cutting costs and boosting user numbers. Snap faces intense competition from Facebook and needs to broaden its appeal beyond its young demographic to older users and expand its advertising base.

title: Why Baidu Stock Fell 32.3% in 2018
summary: Baidu's stock decreased by 32.3% in 2018, primarily due to broader bearish sentiment towards Chinese tech stocks amidst slowing economic growth in China and trade disputes with the U.S., rather than the company's performance. Despite solid earnings and innovation, concerns about market conditions and potential regulatory roadblocks for online content weighed on investor confidence. The stock now trades at 15 times expected earnings, presenting a potential long-term opportunity for investors seeking exposure to Chinese tech, particularly given Baidu's dominant search position and growth in AI, autonomous vehicles, and cloud computing.

title: Xpeng Motors debuts at Auto Shanghai 2019, premiering the Xpeng P7 intelligent electric coupe
summary: Xpeng Motors unveiled its new production model, the P7 intelligent electric coupe, at Auto Shanghai 2019. The P7 boasts a 4s-to-100km/h acceleration, 600 km+ NEDC range, and a Level 3-ready autonomous driving platform. It combines NVIDIA DRIVE Xavier and Qualcomm Snapdragon 820A processors, and features Xpeng's XPILOT 3.0 autonomous driving system tailored for China's road conditions.

title: Cloud Computing: The Digital Infrastructure Powering Today's Businesses
summary: This article discusses how cloud computing has fundamentally transformed business IT, moving from on-premise infrastructure to remote, scalable services. It highlights the financial advantages, ease of management, flexibility, platform power, interoperability, and enablement of emerging technologies as key drivers of its growth. The article concludes that while cloud adoption is still relatively early, it is becoming a foundational tool for businesses of all sizes, with increasing spending and widespread implementation expected.

title: Reliability at heart of Lyft and Uber’s tech, IPOs reveal
summary: This article examines the critical role of reliable technology for rideshare giants Lyft and Uber, as revealed in their IPO filings. It compares their cloud strategies, infrastructure, workforce, and cybersecurity approaches, highlighting how technological reliability underpins their operations and growth in competitive markets. Both companies emphasize data-driven insights and scalable platforms, while also navigating significant challenges like security breaches and regulatory complexities.

title: Publicis Buys Alliance Data’s Epsilon for $4.4 Billion in Cash
summary: Publicis Groupe SA is set to acquire Alliance Data Systems Corp.'s digital marketing firm Epsilon for $4.4 billion in cash, marking its largest takeover to date. This move aims to bolster Publicis's presence in the digital marketing sector amid a competitive landscape against tech giants and consulting firms. The acquisition is intended to be fully debt-financed, leading Publicis to suspend its share buyback program.

title: NetApp CEO sees integration as the core asset in a hybrid world
summary: NetApp CEO George Kurian discusses how integration forms the core asset in a hybrid, multicloud world, emphasizing a data-centric approach over process-centric or system-centric models. He highlights the necessity of a data fabric to stitch together diverse platform elements, enabling organizations to operate the hybrid world as an integrated data layer. Kurian also touches upon the accelerating pace of change in the industry and the need for IT to create vertically integrated squads for faster innovation.

title: Lemonade Raises $300 Million to Fuel Expansion
summary: Lemonade, a tech-driven insurance startup, announced a $300 million funding round led by SoftBank Group Corp. The company plans to use the funds to expand in the United States, launch in Europe, and broaden its product offerings beyond home and rental insurance. This investment brings Lemonade's total funding to $480 million, enabling it to further its mission of shaking up the insurance sector with technology.

title: Whitney High Student and World Math Champion Hannah Chen Receives Edison Scholarship
summary: Whitney High School senior Hannah Chen was surprised with a $40,000 Edison Scholars check. She is one of 30 recipients chosen from 722 applicants who live in SCE’s service area, have at least a 3.0 GPA, show financial need, and plan to pursue STEM studies. Chen, a World Math Team USA champion, plans to major in computer science at California Institute of Technology and hopes to design a system to predict and prevent future forest fires.
