title: Qualcomm aims to take on Nvidia, Intel with new AI chips
summary: Qualcomm is entering the artificial intelligence chip market with its new Cloud AI 100 chip, aiming to compete with Nvidia and Intel. The company plans to target smaller, simpler data centers with power-efficient chips designed for "inference" tasks, leveraging its expertise from mobile phone chip development. Testing with partners like Microsoft is expected to begin later this year, with mass production in 2020.

title: Intel and Google Cloud Announce Strategic Partnership to Accelerate Hybrid Cloud
summary: Intel and Google Cloud announced a strategic partnership to accelerate hybrid cloud adoption for enterprise customers. They will collaborate on Anthos, a new reference design based on the 2nd-Generation Intel Xeon Scalable processor and an optimized Kubernetes software stack, to simplify application deployment across on-premise and cloud environments. This initiative aims to provide customers with increased workload portability and optimized solutions for their data-centric needs.

title: Microsoft staff email chain prompts sexual harassment investigations
summary: Microsoft's executive leadership team is investigating allegations of sexual harassment and discrimination that emerged from a 90-page employee email chain. The company's chief people officer has acknowledged the allegations and plans to create forums for feedback. This incident follows a previous gender discrimination lawsuit against Microsoft and highlights ongoing challenges within the tech industry regarding workplace misconduct.

title: 'Treated as cheap labor': Disney underpays women, lawsuit alleges
summary: The Walt Disney Company is facing a class-action lawsuit alleging systematic underpayment of women and "widespread" discrimination. The lawsuit comes just after Disney's acquisition of 21st Century Fox and follows a report that the company pays men 22% more on average than women in the UK. Two longtime female employees, LaRonda Rasmussen and Karen Moore, allege significant pay disparities compared to male counterparts despite similar roles and experience.

title: Strengths in the SWOT analysis of Motorola Inc :
summary: This article provides a comprehensive SWOT analysis of Motorola Inc., a technology and communications company. It details the company's strengths, such as its diverse product portfolio and global presence, and discusses weaknesses like past failures to adapt to new technologies. The analysis also identifies opportunities in the growing demand for feature phones and emerging economies, as well as threats from intense competition and high investment requirements.

title: How Netflix plans on owning your kids’ screen time
summary: Netflix is heavily investing in children's animation, spending an estimated $1.1 billion this year, to appeal to its broad global subscriber base and fend off competition. Unlike traditional studios, Netflix aims for a diverse range of content without a singular "brand" to cater to every household member's viewing preferences. The company is encouraging creators to pursue unique visions and is experimenting with new interactive features to engage young viewers.

title: 'Apex Legends' boosts Electronic Arts
summary: Electronic Arts Inc. is seeing a significant boost due to the success of its new free-to-play game, "Apex Legends," which generated $92 million in its first month and is poised for further growth with the introduction of battle passes. This resurgence coincides with a general increase in digital game spending worldwide, driving up stock prices for EA and other major video game publishers. However, Epic Games' "Fortnite" has also gained a substantial number of new users, matching "Apex Legends'" user base since its release.

title: Tesla sues former employees for allegedly stealing data, Autopilot source code
summary: Tesla Inc. has filed a lawsuit against a former engineer, Guangzhi Cao, for allegedly copying Autopilot source code before joining Chinese self-driving car startup Xiaopeng Motors. Separately, Tesla also sued four former employees and U.S. self-driving car startup Zoox Inc. for stealing proprietary information related to warehousing and logistics. Xiaopeng Motors has stated it's investigating the allegations against Cao, while Tesla continues to protect its intellectual property in the competitive self-driving car market.

title: Vonvon introduces new game where players control story
summary: Korean mobile entertainment start-up Vonvon announced a new interactive storytelling game called "Maybe," developed in cooperation with Naver. The game, set to launch next month, allows players to make choices that influence the storyline and features characters from Naver Webtoons. Vonvon, a four-year-old company, generated 19.5 billion won ($17.3 million) in revenue last year, primarily from overseas viewers, and is expanding its platform offerings.

title: Developers Lean on Joint Ventures to Fund Hyperscale Data Centers
summary: Data center developers are increasingly using joint ventures to fund the construction of hyperscale data centers due to the enormous capital requirements of such projects. This strategy allows even large publicly traded developers like Digital Realty Trust and QTS Realty to partner with institutional investors, who are eager to invest in data centers leased to investment-grade cloud providers. Joint ventures provide a mechanism for developers to access significant capital, monetize existing assets, and reduce reliance on equity markets to fund future growth.

title: Why Now Might Be a Good Time to Buy QQQ
summary: This article discusses reasons why the Invesco QQQ ETF could be a good investment. It highlights QQQ's focus on large-cap growth, particularly in technology and related sectors, its strong historical performance relative to the S&P 500, and its high liquidity. The article also touches on potential risks like sector concentration and higher volatility compared to broader market indices.

title: If you’re tracking the S&P 500 instead of this fund, you’re leaving money on the table
summary: This article suggests that investors tracking the S&P 500 might be missing out on better returns by overlooking the Invesco QQQ Trust. It highlights the Invesco QQQ Trust as a successful and diversified fund. The piece also addresses concerns about tech stock valuations, noting they are lower than before the dot-com bubble burst.

title: If you’re tracking the S&P 500 instead of this fund, you’re leaving money on the table
summary: The article suggests that investors tracking the S&P 500 might be missing out on better performance by not considering the Invesco QQQ Trust. It highlights QQQ as a successful and diversified alternative, noting that even with "FAANG" company dominance, valuations are lower than during the dot-com bubble. The piece advocates for diversification beyond traditional S&P 500 index funds for retirement savers.

title: Anghami now has over 21 million MAUs, 1 million paying subscribers and it’s not afraid of competition...
summary: Anghami, a Beirut-based music streaming service in MENA, has reported over 21 million monthly active users and 1 million paying subscribers. Co-founder Elie Habib stated that the company is not concerned about competition from Spotify or Deezer, viewing piracy and YouTube as bigger rivals, and highlights Anghami's strategic partnerships with mobile networks in the region.

title: Forbes' billionaires list includes 20 from Michigan
summary: Forbes' annual list of the world's richest people includes 20 individuals with ties to Michigan, ten of whom currently reside in the state. The article highlights each Michigan-connected billionaire, detailing their net worth, global ranking, and their connection to the Great Lakes State. Notable figures include Larry Page, Steve Ballmer, and various business leaders from prominent Michigan companies like Meijer, Quicken Loans, and Stryker Corp.

title: More customers are using Xcel Energy’s mobile app
summary: Xcel Energy's mobile app, launched in 2017, has been downloaded over 400,000 times by customers across its eight-state service area, indicating a growing adoption rate. The app offers features like outage reporting, billing information, energy usage tracking, and a secure payment portal, enhancing customer convenience and access to service details. David Hudson, president of Xcel Energy – New Mexico, Texas, highlights the company's commitment to improving customer experience by providing accessible information and tools.

title: A new billionaire emerges from S'pore gaming powerhouse Sea
summary: Forrest Li, the Chinese-born founder of Singapore-based gaming and e-commerce company Sea Ltd., has become a new billionaire due to the success of Sea's mobile game "Free Fire" and strong sales growth. His 13.8 percent stake in Sea is now worth approximately $1 billion following a 35 percent surge in the company's shares. Despite widening net losses, investors are optimistic about Sea's expansion into e-commerce and its potential to become a regional internet-services powerhouse, similar to its backer Tencent Holdings Ltd.

title: Here are the top 10 self-made richest women in India
summary: The Hurun’s India Rich List of 2018 highlights the top 10 self-made richest women in India, led by Biocon's Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw. The list features prominent figures such as PepsiCo's ex-CEO Indra Nooyi and Jayshree Ullal of Arista Network, showcasing women who have built significant wealth through their entrepreneurial ventures and leadership roles. Companies represented include biopharma, networking, healthcare technology, and consumer goods.

title: Special report: Sophisticated ad fraud permeates the mobile app ecosystem
summary: This report details how sophisticated ad fraud has become an endemic problem within the mobile app ecosystem, affecting both Android and iOS platforms. It covers various fraudulent techniques such as unviewable ads, bad traffic, synthetic audiences, and click injection, highlighting the significant financial and personal costs to users, advertisers, and the industry. Case studies including apps from Cheetah Mobile, Kika Tech, and GOMO illustrate the pervasive nature of these fraudulent activities and the challenges in detection and regulation.

title: Microsoft boosts HoloLens performance, seeking corporate users
summary: Microsoft is launching an improved version of its HoloLens augmented reality goggles, the HoloLens 2, aimed at corporate users, with a lower price point and enhanced features. The company is positioning the device as a tool for various industries, including healthcare and manufacturing, and is also offering it via a monthly subscription. This move reflects Microsoft's strategy to democratize AI and mixed reality technology and generate revenue beyond device sales through cloud software.

title: Alphabet Dethrones Amazon As Top U.S. Internet Company: Citi Report
summary: Citigroup has re-ranked Alphabet as the top U.S. internet company, surpassing Amazon, due to its strong growth in mobile search and YouTube, stock buybacks, and high valuation. Amazon's downgrade to fourth place is attributed to slower growth, regulatory challenges in India, and distractions from its HQ2 plans and CEO's personal issues. This re-ranking coincides with Google Cloud's aggressive investment in its sales division and increased competition with Amazon Web Services and Microsoft Azure.

title: Google confirms plans to expand in Cambridge's Kendall Square
summary: Google has confirmed its plans to expand its presence in Kendall Square, Cambridge, by occupying a new glass tower. This expansion marks a significant development for the technology giant in the area. The article references previous related developments and proposals for Google's presence in Kendall Square.

title: Johnson & Johnson to buy surgical robotics firm Auris for $3.4 billion
summary: Johnson & Johnson announced its acquisition of Auris Health Inc for $3.4 billion in cash, marking its expansion into the rapidly growing healthcare robotics market. This strategic move aims to bolster J&J's medical device business and leverage Auris's surgical robotic scope used in respiratory procedures and lung cancer detection. The deal is expected to create a formidable competitor, particularly for current market leader Intuitive Surgical.

title: Google selects Equinix for submarine cable landing station in LA
summary: Google has chosen Equinix's LA4 data center as the landing point for its upcoming Curie submarine cable, which will connect the US with Chile. This marks the first direct submarine link between the two countries in 20 years. The cable, named after Marie Skłodowska Curie, will stretch over 10,000 km and aims to meet the increasing demand for high-capacity, low-latency global connectivity.

title: Dandelion Energy Raises $16 Million Led by Google Ventures and Comcast
summary: Dandelion Energy, a leading home geothermal company, has completed a Series A funding round of $16 million, bringing its total funding to $23 million. The round was co-led by GV (formerly Google Ventures) and Comcast Ventures, with participation from Lennar Corporation and existing investors. Dandelion plans to use the funding to accelerate growth, invest in R&D, and expand operations across New York State, aiming to make geothermal heating and cooling economically viable for millions of homeowners by reducing installation costs.

title: A Storm Is Coming to the Global Music Industry — and More than $100 Billion Is at Stake
summary: Vivendi is selling up to 50% of Universal Music Group, and its projected astronomical valuation could significantly impact the valuations of rivals Sony Music and Warner Music Group. Analysts from Deutsche Bank, Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, and Exane BNP Paribas have provided valuations for UMG ranging from $29 billion to $42 billion, with a "bull case" scenario for Morgan Stanley suggesting even higher figures based on streaming growth. This potential Universal Music Group supersale could lead to a combined valuation for the "big three" music companies exceeding $100 billion, driven by intense market demand and optimistic streaming forecasts.

title: Amazon Eases Into Self-Driving Tech By Joining Aurora's $530 Million Funding Surge
summary: Aurora, a self-driving technology startup founded by leading researchers, secured over $530 million in Series B funding, with Amazon making a significant investment. The company aims to develop autonomous vehicle technology for other manufacturers rather than building its own fleet. This substantial funding injection underscores the capital-intensive nature of autonomous driving development and Amazon's interest in logistics and goods movement.

title: Silicon Valley's highest-paid CEOs may surprise you
summary: This article from the Silicon Valley Business Journal reveals the highest-paid CEOs in Silicon Valley for 2019, highlighting some lesser-known executives at the top of the list. John Donahoe of ServiceNow Inc. is identified as the highest-paid CEO with total compensation of $41.52 million. The piece suggests that the typical highest-paid CEOs might not be the most obvious names.

title: Taiwanese manufacturers are expecting an increase in OLED production and demand
summary: Taiwanese manufacturers like AU Optronics and Novatek Microelectronics are anticipating a massive surge in OLED display demand and are adjusting their production to meet it. The growth is leading established players to ramp up output for Android devices and iPhones, while newcomers like Novatek Microelectronics and Himax Technologies are entering the market focusing on OLED driver ICs. This trend is also observed with other Asian companies, highlighting a widespread belief in the continued expansion of the OLED market.

title: What’s Changed: 2019 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Data Management Solutions for Analytics
summary: This article reviews the 2019 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Data Management Solutions for Analytics (DMSA), highlighting key changes since the previous report. It discusses shifts in vendor positions, new entrants, and removals, focusing on the evolution of major players like Oracle, Microsoft, Amazon Web Services, SAP, Teradata, IBM, Snowflake, Google, and MarkLogic. The article also touches upon the general trends in DMSA, emphasizing the growing importance of cloud and the diverse approaches taken by niche and leading providers.

title: Why You Should Include ETFs in Your Portfolio
summary: ETFs offer a convenient and easy way to diversify a portfolio, combining features of individual stocks and mutual funds. They allow investors to participate in entire sectors, avoid single stock risk, and benefit from lower fees and greater tax efficiency compared to traditional mutual funds. The article also covers how to choose and purchase ETFs, as well as several investing strategies.

title: January 2019 Newsletter: 4 Charts Every Investor Should Know
summary: This January 2019 newsletter by Lyn Alden discusses major market drivers for 2019, highlighting high asset valuations and global leverage. It presents four key charts investors should know: corporate debt, central bank balance sheets, net worth to income, and the U.S. federal deficit and debt to GDP, to help balance risk and reward. The article also provides detailed portfolio updates and investment strategy recommendations focusing on dividends and defensive positioning.

title: Google Cloud Acquisition Targets: ServiceNow, Atlassian, Splunk? Pure Speculation
summary: This article speculates on potential acquisition targets for Google Cloud Platform (GCP) to help it close the revenue gap with AWS and Azure, specifically mentioning ServiceNow, Atlassian, Splunk, and Zayo. It analyzes the pros and cons of each potential deal, highlighting challenges related to market capitalization, sales models, and integration for each company. The author concludes that while Wall Street speculates, there are no credible reports of actual takeover discussions.

title: The No. 1 Airline App Just Got Better - United Airlines Introduces Upgraded App
summary: United Airlines has launched a reimagined mobile app to enhance customer experience, building on its position as the top-downloaded airline app. The updated app features a dynamic design to provide relevant information throughout the travel journey, new navigation and "My Trips" tab, an inbox for notifications, and personalized content, all based on extensive customer and employee feedback. This initiative reinforces United's commitment to using technology to make travel easier and more intuitive for its customers.

title: Developers of Driverless Cars Taking A More Cautious, Low-Key Approach
summary: The driverless car industry is adopting a more cautious and low-key approach after previous bold claims and incidents like the fatal Uber crash. Companies like Aptiv, Toyota, and Waymo are emphasizing safety and more restrained deployments, focusing on specific routes and lower speeds, with full autonomy taking longer to achieve. The article highlights the increased recognition of the complexity and challenges involved in industrializing autonomous vehicle technology.

title: Google spends $40 million on Fossil smartwatch tech
summary: Google has agreed to acquire smartwatch technology and personnel from Fossil Group Inc. for US$40 million. This move aims to bolster Google's presence in the smartwatch market, where its Wear OS platform has lagged behind competitors like Apple. The acquisition includes intellectual property not yet released to the market and transfers an unspecified number of Fossil's R&D employees to Google, while Fossil retains 200 people in its smartwatch division.

title: TVA announces solar farms to serve Google data centers
summary: The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) announced new solar farm deals with NextEra Energy Resources and Invenergy to power Google's data centers in Alabama and Tennessee. These two solar farms will provide 300 megawatts of carbon-free renewable power, contributing to Google's commitment to 100% renewable energy. The initiative is part of TVA's efforts to attract and retain top-tier companies by providing cleaner, low-cost electricity and significantly increases solar capacity in the region.

title: With Google project, Minnesota joins the boom in megasized data centers
summary: Minnesota is set to join the growing trend of megasized data centers with Google Inc.'s proposed project near the Sherco power generating station in Becker, Minn. This $600 million facility will consume significant electricity and contribute to the regional boom in "hyperscale" data centers being built by major tech companies. While these centers employ few people once operational, their construction phases provide hundreds of jobs, particularly for skilled electricians, and are critical for the infrastructure of cloud-based computing.

title: Google Signs Lease For Once Bustling Westside Pavilion Shopping Center
summary: Google has signed a 14-year lease for the entire 584,000-square-foot redevelopment of the former Westside Pavilion shopping mall in Los Angeles, transforming it into a "creative office campus" called One Westside. The lease is set to begin in 2022 after construction completion, marking Google's continued expansion following other significant real estate investments in New York City. This move highlights the growing tech and media industries in Los Angeles and the repurposing of traditional retail spaces for modern office needs.

title: Resideo Unveils A New Degree Of Whole Home Comfort At CES 2019
summary: Resideo announced its new Honeywell Home T-Series Smart Thermostats (T9 and T10 Pro) at CES 2019, featuring innovative wireless smart room sensors. These thermostats aim to provide whole-home comfort by adjusting temperatures where and when needed, optimizing for sleep at night and energy savings when away. The T9 model offers DIY installation, while the T10 Pro is professionally installed and includes humidity and ventilation controls.

title: Philips Cares digitizes the aging and caregiving experience
summary: Royal Philips launched Philips Cares in the U.S. at CES 2019, a new digital experience designed to support family caregivers and their aging loved ones. This service creates a care circle of trusted contacts, provides insights into a loved one's well-being, and allows for managing Philips Lifeline personal alert services. The aim is to ease the caregiving journey by leveraging digital technology, allowing caregivers to stay informed and connected.

title: For Many Builders, Smart Homes Now Come Standard
summary: New-home builders are increasingly integrating smart home technology as a standard feature due to its widespread adoption and affordability. Companies like Meritage Homes and Lennar are partnering with tech giants such as Amazon, Google, and Apple to offer various smart devices and services, aiming to meet consumer demand and differentiate new constructions from existing homes. This shift is driven by consumer expectations and the decreasing cost of smart home tech, making it a compelling baseline amenity for new builds.

title: Is Apple Still a ‘forever’ Company? How About Facebook?
summary: This article questions the "forever company" thesis for tech giants like Apple and Facebook, highlighting recent market shifts and challenges. It discusses how Apple's plunging shares due to demand issues in China and Nokia's past trajectory suggest even dominant companies face significant hurdles. The piece also explores the concept of S-curves in technology, suggesting that while current tech giants are strong, a new S-curve, potentially augmented reality or AI, could reset the competitive landscape.

title: Netflix Just Made a Truly Radical Change Affecting Millions of New Subscribers, and It's Totally Brilliant. (Or Maybe Insane--Time Will Tell)
summary: Netflix has implemented a significant change by no longer allowing new subscribers to pay via iTunes, aiming to avoid the substantial "Apple tax" of 15% to 30% on subscription revenue. This strategic move, which could save Netflix hundreds of millions, shifts new users to subscribe directly through the Netflix app, cutting Apple out of its commission. While potentially risking some new subscribers, Netflix is betting that its strong demand across platforms will outweigh any losses and make the decision financially brilliant in the long run.

title: Roomba vacuum maker to up China investment, expand the market
summary: US-based iRobot Corp, known for its Roomba robot vacuum cleaners, plans to increase investment in research and development and expand its manufacturing operations in China, recognizing the country's significance to its growth strategy. China is currently iRobot's fastest-growing and fourth-largest market, prompting the company to tailor products for the local market and establish a dedicated commercial team in Shanghai. The company is also collaborating with Google LLC to integrate robotic and smart home technologies, while rival Xiaomi Corp is also expanding its smart home offerings in China.

title: 3M completes acquisition of MModal’s tech business for $1B
summary: 3M has completed its acquisition of MModal's technology business for $1 billion. MModal specializes in cloud-based, AI-powered speech technology and clinical documentation tools, which 3M plans to integrate into its Health Information Systems business, particularly for revenue cycle management and population health. The deal is expected to enhance 3M's offerings in an area of growing demand for speech recognition technology in healthcare.

title: Advertising: Why billboards and outdoor ads are booming in a smartphone age
summary: Despite the rise of digital advertising and smartphone addiction, billboards and outdoor ads are experiencing a resurgence. Major tech companies like Netflix, Apple, Google, and Amazon are investing heavily in out-of-home advertising, which offers relevance and bypasses ad-blocking software. The integration of technology, data, and programmatic buying is making these traditional ad formats more interactive, targeted, and effective in capturing consumer attention.

title: IonQ Quantum Computer Delivers More Processing Power Than Google's
summary: IonQ has announced a new trapped ion quantum computer with 79 processing qubits, claiming it will surpass Google's 72-qubit quantum computer in both qubit count and overall processing performance. The IonQ computer has already set a world record for a particular problem using the Bernstein-Vazirani Algorithm, achieving a 73% success rate, significantly higher than any other quantum computer. IonQ plans to make its trapped-ion quantum computers available to researchers in 2019 for various applications.

title: Digital Data Gives Billboard Owners More Reason to ‘Love a Good Traffic Jam’
summary: Outdoor advertising companies like Lamar Advertising and Clear Channel Outdoor are leveraging digital data from mobile devices to understand driver demographics, dwell time, and shopping habits, turning increased traffic into a valuable opportunity. This data helps them target ads more effectively, even discovering counterintuitive correlations like fast-food customers also frequenting gyms due to lengthy commutes. The growing average commute time in the U.S. creates a captive audience that these companies are now able to analyze and monetize with greater precision.

title: Working in shadows at Google
summary: Google heavily relies on a large contract workforce, known as "TVCs," who now outnumber direct employees. These contractors, despite often doing similar work, lack the benefits and opportunities afforded to full-time staff, leading to feelings of being "second-class citizens" and raising concerns among both contractors and full employees. The reliance on contractors helps Google keep official headcount low and manage costs, but Google distances itself from responsibility for their pay, benefits, and grievances, despite asserting authority on intellectual property matters.

title: Yahoo parent Verizon cuts value of media brands by $4.6bn
summary: Verizon has slashed the collective value of its digital media brands, including Huffington Post, Yahoo, and AOL, by $4.6 billion, reducing Oath's worth to approximately $200 million. This write-down reflects challenging conditions for digital media companies, a stark contrast to their earlier valuations, and signals difficulties for Verizon's ambition to rival Google and Facebook. The struggling valuations of other digital media companies like Vice Media and BuzzFeed are also highlighted, suggesting a trend of consolidation.

title: Google, Netflix, Costco ranked among top companies for diversity by workers
summary: Google, Netflix, and Costco have been recognized among the top companies for diversity, according to a survey by Comparably. The ranking defines diversity based on how non-Caucasian employees rate their workplace experiences. A consistent focus on diversity from leadership at all levels contributed to the high marks received by these companies.

title: How To Engage Millennials Via Native Advertising
summary: This article discusses how to effectively engage millennials through native advertising, highlighting their significant spending power and tech-driven nature. It emphasizes that native advertising aligns well with how millennials consume content, offering three key guidelines: make ads interactive, personalize content to avoid stereotypes, and create an "experience" rather than just selling a product. The piece stresses the importance of trust, influencer marketing, and mobile-friendly content for reaching this audience.

title: Janus Henderson: Tech market sell-off - the bigger picture
summary: Alison Porter, Richard Clode, and Graeme Clark from Janus Henderson’s Global Technology Team discuss the recent tech market sell-off, attributing it to a combination of factors including rising bond yields, trade war concerns, and inventory correction in semiconductors. They highlight that despite the volatility, the long-term secular drivers for the technology sector remain strong, and valuations are becoming more attractive. The team emphasizes their valuation-disciplined investment style and focus on quality companies benefiting from powerful secular themes.

title: Taking aim at Intel, Qualcomm launches chip for business PCs
summary: Qualcomm has launched a new series of chips, the Snapdragon 8cx, specifically designed for business PCs to directly compete with Intel. These new chips will support Windows 10 Enterprise, addressing a limitation of previous Qualcomm chips that only supported consumer versions of Windows. This move intensifies Qualcomm's competition with Intel, which has historically dominated the PC chip market and is also being challenged in the data center business.

title: Google, IBM, Oracle to Talk Tech at White House Amid Trade War
summary: Technology industry leaders from Google, IBM, Oracle, Microsoft, and Qualcomm are set to attend a White House summit to discuss emerging innovations like artificial intelligence. The meeting takes place against the backdrop of the administration's ongoing trade war with China. Attendees include Sundar Pichai, Ginni Rometty, Safra Catz, Satya Nadella, and Steve Mollenkopf.

title: Apple shifts marketing staff to boost sagging iPhone sales
summary: Apple is implementing aggressive marketing strategies, including discount promotions and moving staff, to boost sagging iPhone sales, especially for the iPhone XS and XR models. This comes amidst waning demand, a cut sales forecast from a supplier, and Apple's decision to stop reporting iPhone unit sales, leading to a drop in its stock value and concerns about market saturation. The company is actively exploring new growth engines beyond the iPhone, such as augmented reality, driverless cars, and subscription services, while also facing challenges in emerging markets like India.

title: Command & Conquer: Rivals Launches Worldwide, Brings Competitive Real-Time Strategy Excitement to Mobile
summary: Electronic Arts Inc. has officially launched Command & Conquer: Rivals, a fast-paced, real-time strategy action game for Android and iOS devices, aiming to bring competitive RTS excitement to mobile. The game emphasizes player versus player gameplay with intuitive controls, offering factions like the Global Defense Initiative and the Brotherhood of Nod. EA is also expanding its competitive gaming roster with Rivals Champions, an exclusive in-game weekend event and a planned multi-continent esports program in 2019.

title: How Morgan Stanley's 'mad scientist' became the top Wall Street analyst on the space industry
summary: Adam Jonas, Morgan Stanley's auto analyst, has become the firm's leading expert on the space industry, a shift driven by his interest in Elon Musk's ventures. Initially met with skepticism, Jonas and his team have built a comprehensive research effort on space, anticipating significant growth, akin to the self-driving car market. He believes catalysts like a Chinese lunar mission or a major tech company's satellite launch could rapidly accelerate market appreciation for space investments.

title: Amazon's latest gadget - a self-driving toy car for coders
summary: Amazon's cloud unit announced a $399 autonomous toy car called AWS DeepRacer, aimed at helping web developers experiment with self-driving technology through machine learning models in an online simulator. Amazon Web Services is also launching a global autonomous racing league using the toy cars to further engage developers and promote its machine learning services. This move highlights Amazon's increasing interest in the autonomous vehicle sector and its potential in engaging developers with new technologies.

title: 4 steps SMEs can take for their development and long-term business success
summary: Small-to-medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are crucial to modern economies, accounting for a significant portion of businesses, employment, and GDP. This article outlines four key steps SMEs can take to ensure their development and long-term business success: attracting the right talent, creating agility through horizontal management, harnessing digital technology, and being part of a relevant value chain. The author emphasizes that governments and strategic partnerships also play a critical role in fostering a supportive environment for SME growth.

title: The Walt Disney Company Will Now Use Google Technology for Its Digital Ads
summary: The Walt Disney Company has partnered with Google to use Google Ad Manager for delivering digital video and display ads across its various brands. This new agreement replaces Disney's previous relationship with Comcast's ad serving platform, FreeWheel. The partnership aims to transform the advertising experience and allows Disney Advertising Sales to sell cross-platform ads for its extensive portfolio, including Disney, ABC, ESPN, Freeform, Star Wars, Marvel, and Pixar.

title: These Hugely Popular Android Apps Have Been Committing Ad Fraud Behind Users’ Backs
summary: Eight popular Android apps, primarily owned by Chinese companies Cheetah Mobile and Kika Tech, with over 2 billion downloads, have been implicated in an ad fraud scheme called "click flooding" and "click injection." This scheme exploits app permissions to falsely claim credit for app installations, potentially stealing millions of dollars in bounties. Research from Kochava and Method Media Intelligence highlighted how these apps manipulate attribution systems to earn fees even when they played no role in a user downloading another app, raising significant concerns about security, privacy, and ad fraud in the Android ecosystem.

title: Egyptian transportation startup Swvl raises tens of millions in Series B at valuation close to $100 million, plans expansion to Southeast Asia
summary: Egyptian transportation startup Swvl has raised tens of millions in its Series B round, valuing the company close to $100 million, making it a first for an Egyptian company with publicly disclosed data. The funding, co-led by Dubai-based BECO Capital, Africa-based DiGAME, and Silicon Badia, will fuel Swvl's expansion into Southeast Asia, targeting megacities in the Philippines, Vietnam, and Thailand, and establishing an R&D facility in Berlin. Swvl aims to become a multi-billion dollar tech company focused on solving commuting challenges in emerging markets through its app-based bus booking service.

title: Apple's stock rout starts and ends with the iPhone
summary: Apple's stock is experiencing a significant downturn, falling more than 20 percent from its all-time highs and shedding over $100 billion from its market valuation. This rout is primarily attributed to weakening iPhone sales, lower-than-expected shipments, and warnings of lighter holiday sales, leading to negative sentiment among investors. Despite growth in Services and Other Products, the iPhone remains Apple's largest revenue segment, and its struggles are impacting the company's overall performance.

title: Google’s new cloud CEO is Thomas Kurian
summary: Thomas Kurian has been appointed as the new CEO of Google Cloud, succeeding Diane Greene. Kurian, formerly a key executive at Oracle, is tasked with bolstering Google Cloud's market share against competitors like AWS and Microsoft by positioning Google as a serious enterprise player. His background and industry contacts are expected to be valuable assets in attracting large companies to Google's cloud infrastructure.

title: Marc Benioff defends Salesforce’s contract with Customs and Border Protection
summary: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff defended his company's contract with U.S. Customs and Border Protection amidst criticism from employees and others concerned about the agency's role in family separation. Benioff emphasized the launch of an Office of Ethical and Humane Use of Technology to guide the company's approach to the use of its software. He highlighted that tech companies are entering a "new world" where the ethical use of their technology, whether by government or corporations, needs constant examination.

title: Unlocking Industry 4.0 with Cutting-Edge Technologies
summary: This article explores the transformative impact of technologies like AI, Robotics, IoT, and Blockchain on Industry 4.0, particularly in energy and commodities. It discusses the evolution of Commodity/Energy Trading and Risk Management (C/ETRM) systems and the potential of blockchain to introduce transparency, liquidity, and efficiency. The piece also addresses the challenges and the strategic approach required for successful blockchain implementation, emphasizing the need to understand its true capabilities and manage expectations.

title: Google hires former Oracle exec Thomas Kurian to be new cloud CEO
summary: Former Oracle Corp product chief Thomas Kurian is set to replace Diane Greene as the head of Alphabet Inc's Google Cloud division. Greene announced her departure, stating she would move into investing and philanthropy after three years at Google. Kurian's appointment comes after a challenging year for Google Cloud, including employee protests over military contracts and a withdrawal from bidding on a major defense cloud computing contract.

title: Google parent Alphabet’s stock becomes 2nd FANG to produce ‘death cross’ and Netflix is next
summary: Google parent Alphabet Inc.'s stock (GOOGL) has formed a "death cross" chart pattern for the first time in over two years, indicating a potential bearish trend. This marks Alphabet as the second FANG stock to experience this pattern, with Netflix expected to be next. The death cross occurs when the 50-day moving average falls below the 200-day moving average, which chart watchers interpret as a long-term bearish signal.

title: Oracle veteran Thomas Kurian to head Google Cloud
summary: Thomas Kurian, a former Oracle Corp product chief, will replace Diane Greene as the head of Google Cloud. Kurian, who spent 22 years at Oracle, resigned in September and will join Google on November 26th. This leadership change occurs as Google Cloud aims to expand its enterprise business and compete with rivals like Amazon.com Inc and Microsoft Corp.

title: Google Cloud CEO to depart and be replaced by former Oracle president
summary: Diane Greene, CEO of Alphabet Inc.'s Google Cloud division, is stepping down and will be replaced by former Oracle Corp. executive Thomas Kurian. Greene plans to focus on mentoring female startup founders. The change in leadership was announced on Friday.

title: Ford, Walmart to Test Self-Driving Grocery Delivery Service
summary: Ford Motor Co. and Walmart Inc. are collaborating to test a self-driving grocery delivery service, building on an existing partnership with Postmates. The initiative involves Ford vehicles simulating autonomous deliveries to understand consumer interaction without human drivers, aiming to significantly cut shipping costs. This move highlights the growing interest of automakers and tech companies in autonomous delivery as a potentially lucrative application of self-driving technology.

title: Airbnb Ends Forced Arbitration for Discrimination and Harassment
summary: Airbnb has announced it will no longer force employees who file sexual harassment and discrimination claims into private arbitration. This move follows similar actions by other tech companies like Google, Facebook, and Uber for sexual harassment cases. Airbnb states it is the first major technology company to remove binding arbitration for discrimination cases as well.

title: Amazon strikes deal with Apple to sell iPhones, iPads
summary: Amazon.com Inc has announced a deal with Apple Inc to sell a wider range of Apple products globally, including iPhones and iPads, starting in time for the holiday shopping season. This agreement marks a shift for brands like Apple and Nike, which previously limited distribution through Amazon, as they increasingly recognize the e-commerce giant as a crucial channel for customer reach. The partnership also means Amazon will remove unauthorized third-party sellers of Apple products from its site.

title: GE Or IBM: Which Turnaround Stock Is The Better Value Right Now?
summary: This article compares General Electric (GE) and International Business Machines (IBM) as turnaround stocks for contrarian investors, highlighting their respective challenges and potential. GE faces a cash crunch and skepticism regarding its restructuring, while IBM struggles with adapting to new technologies but shows promise in cloud computing and AI. The author suggests IBM might be the better bet due to its clear strategic direction and lower valuation compared to tech peers.

title: Universal becomes first major to license Africa’s biggest streaming platform, Boomplay
summary: Universal Music Group has licensed its catalog to Boomplay, Africa's most popular streaming service, becoming the first major music company to do so. This deal provides UMG's African and international artists access to Boomplay's 36 million users, enhancing streaming experiences for fans, artists, and songwriters in the region. Boomplay, owned by Chinese companies Transsion Holdings and NetEase, plans an iOS release soon, expanding its reach across multiple African countries.

title: Bull Leveraged ETFs Banking on Post-Midterm Election Rally
summary: Leveraged ETFs like Direxion Daily S&P500 Bull 3X ETF (SPXL) and Direxion Daily S&P 500 Bull 2X ETF (SPUU) are positioned to benefit from a potential post-midterm election rally, according to historical data. This comes after a volatile October where U.S. equities experienced significant declines, with the Nasdaq Composite falling 9.2% and the S&P 500 falling 7%. Analysts suggest that despite the recent volatility, historical patterns indicate a strong likelihood of a year-end rally following midterm elections.

title: Netflix Stock Seen Rebounding 10% Short-Term
summary: Despite a recent 24% drop from its mid-July high and a broader tech sell-off, Netflix stock is showing signs of a short-term rebound. Options traders are betting on a 10% increase, while technical analysis suggests the stock is breaking out above resistance. Although analysts cut fourth-quarter profit forecasts, bullish momentum may be returning, making some traders optimistic about Netflix leading a broader market recovery.

title: Artificial intelligence: Investing in a friend and foe
summary: This article discusses the profound impact of artificial intelligence (AI) and the investment opportunities it presents. It highlights AI's rapid advancements, its disruptive potential across various industries, and provides investment options like ETFs for Australian investors, despite some skepticism and challenges.

title: LinkedIn Offers New Integrations with Google Campaign Manager and Vimeo
summary: LinkedIn has announced new integrations designed to enhance marketers' capabilities. One integration is with Google Campaign Manager, allowing for better comparison and management of LinkedIn ad performance alongside other ad efforts in a single dashboard. Additionally, Vimeo now offers a new way for paid subscribers to publish videos directly to their LinkedIn company pages, making it easier to share video content and leverage LinkedIn's high member engagement.

title: 5 Most Important Things in Business Today: IBM M&A
summary: This article highlights five significant business events, including IBM's $34 billion acquisition of Red Hat to boost its cloud computing presence, and an increase in global efforts to tax tech giants like Alphabet and Facebook. It also notes the box office success of "Halloween," improved Japan-China trade relations, and the negative impact of rising interest rates on housing and auto stocks.

title: ‘This Is Surveillance.’ Apple CEO Tim Cook Slams Tech Rivals Over Data Collection
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook criticized tech rivals like Facebook and Google for their data collection practices, equating them to "surveillance" and prioritizing profits over user privacy. This strong rebuke came at an EU privacy conference, highlighting a growing tension between user privacy and advertising-based business models, especially after recent data breaches at Google and Facebook. Cook also called for federal privacy laws in the U.S. similar to Europe's GDPR.

title: Ford's New 'Built Ford Proud' Campaign Takes Telling Shots At Silicon Valley Competitors
summary: Ford's new "Built Ford Proud" ad campaign directly challenges Silicon Valley tech and EV companies, positioning traditional manufacturing against digital innovation. The campaign, starring Bryan Cranston, uses dismissive remarks and imagery to highlight Ford's heritage of building tangible products. This strategy subtly appeals to mainstream Americans' concerns about tech giants and signals a battle for control of the automotive industry's future.

title: ServiceNow sets plans for big expansion in Santa Clara
summary: ServiceNow is planning a significant expansion of its headquarters in Santa Clara, including leasing a new 269,000-square-foot office building expected to be completed in 2021. This expansion reflects the company's rapid growth, with a 28% increase in employee headcount globally in the past year, and is projected to accommodate over a thousand new employees in Santa Clara. The tech company has also extended leases on its existing buildings and currently occupies an additional facility on Jay Street.

title: Palo Alto Networks names Google's Amit Singh as new president
summary: Palo Alto Networks has named former Google executive Amit K. Singh as its new president, effective November 1. Singh, who previously served as VP of business and operations in emerging computing platforms at Google, will succeed Mark Anderson. Palo Alto Networks CEO Nikesh Arora highlighted Singh's experience in growing cloud businesses and driving revenue as key to strengthening the company's cybersecurity leadership.

title: Boris Wertz’s Version One closes third fund, drawing in global investors
summary: Version One Ventures, led by Boris Wertz, has successfully closed its third fund at $57-million, attracting significant international investment from firms like Invesco Ltd. and Sofina SA. This marks a growing trend of global interest in Canadian seed-stage technology startups. The firm will continue its focus on seed-stage companies leveraging "network-effects" and has expanded its scope to include cryptocurrency and digital health-care.

title: Adobe XD now lets you prototype voice apps
summary: Adobe XD is integrating voice app prototyping capabilities, powered by its acquisition of Sayspring. This allows designers to create voice-based applications for platforms like Alexa and Google Home, as well as mobile apps with voice input, mimicking real user experiences with voice triggers and speech playback. Additionally, XD is receiving other new features such as a full range of plugins, auto-animate, drag gestures, and deeper integration with Adobe Illustrator and After Effects.

title: Palo Alto Networks Taps Former Google Exec Amit Singh As President
summary: Palo Alto Networks has appointed Amit Singh, a former Google executive who grew Google Cloud into a multibillion-dollar business, as its new president, effective November 1. Singh worked with current Palo Alto Networks CEO Nikesh Arora at Google and will replace Mark Anderson, who will remain as an advisor until May 2019. Singh's compensation package includes a $750,000 annual salary, a $10 million restricted stock award, and $24.5 million in performance-based stock options.

title: New listings: KWEB comes to London
summary: The KraneShares CSI China Internet ETF (KWEB) is expanding its reach by listing in London, following its success in the US market where it has accumulated $1.3 billion in assets. This move positions KWEB, which tracks Chinese internet companies similar to Google and Amazon, as a direct competitor to the Emerging Markets Ecommerce ETF (EMQQ), both of which heavily weight companies like Baidu, Alibaba, and Tencent. The article highlights that KWEB has faced challenges in 2018 with a -17% YTD return due to China's trade tensions and concerns over tech valuations.

title: How much time do people spend online each day?
summary: This article introduces an insights piece from UKOM investigating the average time people spend online per day in the UK. The report compares online consumption levels across the total UK population, broken down by gender and age groups, versus the total UK digital population by platform. It aims to provide a comprehensive overview of digital engagement.

title: China Airbnb rival Xiaozhu.com raises nearly $300 million from Jack Ma fund
summary: Chinese short-term rental firm Xiaozhu.com has raised nearly $300 million in a funding round led by Jack Ma's Yunfeng Capital. This funding comes amidst intense competition with Airbnb and local rival Tujia.com, as Xiaozhu focuses on value-added services and smart technology from Alibaba to grow in a heavily regulated market.

title: D-Wave takes quantum computers mainstream with ‘Leap’
summary: D-Wave Systems is launching "Leap," a web portal offering immediate, free, real-time access to its quantum computers for developers. This initiative aims to democratize quantum computing, moving it from large corporations and academic institutions to a broader user base. Leap provides not only access but also learning tools, open-source code, and a community forum to foster widespread adoption and application development for quantum technology.

title: Sabre Corp. CEO Sean Menke Is Mapping Out A Bold New Direction
summary: Sean Menke, CEO of Sabre Corp., is leading a significant transformation of the 60-year-old travel technology company through a $1 billion investment in technology and labor, a new executive team, and a refocused vision. Menke's strategic overhaul aims to revitalize Sabre by addressing legacy system issues, improving customer relations, and exploring new verticals to create a seamless travel experience. Despite initial challenges like missed earnings and layoffs, his efforts have led to increased investor confidence and a rising stock price, with analysts noting strengthened long-term travel agency deals.

title: Upwork shares rocket more than 50% higher at the open on their first day of trading
summary: Upwork's IPO saw its shares rocket more than 50% higher on their first day of trading after pricing its initial public offering at $15 per share, above the expected range. CEO Stephane Kasriel stated the IPO was not about raising money but highlighted the company's mission to connect freelancers with clients globally. Upwork, formed from Elance and oDesk, reported strong revenue growth and addressed fair pay, emphasizing that its business model benefits when freelancers earn more.

title: Groupon to pay IBM $57 million to settle U.S. patent dispute
summary: Groupon agreed to pay IBM $57 million to settle a patent dispute over e-commerce technology. This settlement comes after a jury initially sided with IBM, awarding $83 million in damages. The agreement also includes a long-term patent cross-license, allowing Groupon access to IBM's patent portfolio.

title: Michigan, not Silicon Valley, produced Ford's self-driving gurus
summary: This article highlights Bryan Salesky and Pete Rander, the Michigan-native leaders of Argo AI, Ford's self-driving partner. It details their pragmatic approach to developing autonomous vehicles, emphasizing collaboration with Detroit's automotive industry expertise over Silicon Valley's tech-centric view. The piece underscores their belief that existing automotive assets in Michigan are crucial for building effective and safe self-driving cars, and their aim to create a scalable system applicable to various cities.

title: Our Indian engineers are fantastic, says Juniper Networks CEO
summary: Juniper Networks CEO Rami Rahim highlights the significant role of its Indian R&D center, calling its engineers "fantastic" and emphasizing that India is the company's largest development site. He notes that the Indian team owns entire product development cycles for critical routing systems and plays a key role across the technology stack. Rahim also discusses the company's long-term strategy, its growth in India, and the development of AI-driven solutions to predict network issues.

title: How Google’s DeepMind will train its AI inside Unity’s video game worlds
summary: Google's DeepMind is partnering with Unity Technologies to train its AI using reinforcement learning within Unity's 3D video game environments. This collaboration allows AI algorithms to "evolve" by learning through trial and error in physics-realistic virtual worlds, offering a scalable method for developing smarter AI beyond traditional coding. The approach enables training for diverse applications from robot navigation to simulating social dynamics and chemical experiments.

title: A smarter house package from KB Home
summary: KB Home has partnered with Google to launch the KB Smart Home System, an industry-first initiative featuring Google Assistant. This system, including a Google Wi-Fi mesh network, smart speakers, and a Nest Hello Video Doorbell, will be integrated into new homes in select communities. Homeowners will have the ability to automate routines and personalize their living spaces, with plans for future expansion and additional smart home product options.

title: ‘We Do Not Support This Conduct.’ PayPal Joins the Growing Number of Sites to Ban InfoWars
summary: PayPal Holdings Inc. has announced it will no longer offer its services to Alex Jones' InfoWars website due to instances of promoting hate and discriminatory intolerance. This decision aligns PayPal with other major tech companies like Apple, Facebook, Google's YouTube, and Twitter, which have also banned Jones from their platforms. InfoWars claims the ban is a "political ploy designed to financially sabotage" them.

title: GICS Changes: Risk Depends on How It’s Measured
summary: This article discusses the impact of changes to the Global Industry Classification Standard (GICS) on the risk profiles of reclassified companies, particularly those transitioning to the broadened Communications Services sector. It analyzes how these changes affect predicted Beta and total risk for specific large companies, differentiating between those with GICS sector changes only versus those with industry reclassifications within MSCI's Long-Term Global Equity Model. The analysis suggests that while some companies saw little change, those shifting industry factors experienced a noticeable drop in predicted risk.

title: Tech Redefined: S&P 500 Companies Worth $2.7 Trillion Change Sectors Friday
summary: On Friday, 23 S&P 500 companies with a combined value of $2.7 trillion are being reclassified, largely moving out of the technology sector into a new "communication-services" sector. This major rebalancing, impacting over 10% of the S&P 500's market value, will trigger more than $20 billion in stock trades by ETFs and require significant portfolio adjustments from investors. Companies like Facebook, Twitter, Google, Walt Disney Co., Netflix Inc., and Comcast Corp. are among those making the sector shift, representing the most significant overhaul to the Global Industry Classification Standard since 1999.

title: Tech Redefined: S&P 500 Companies Worth $2.7 Trillion Change Sectors Friday
summary: On Friday, 23 S&P 500 companies, including Facebook, Twitter, and Google, valued at a combined $2.7 trillion, were reclassified out of the tech sector as index providers revamped how companies are organized. This shift transformed the telecom sector into a new "communication-services" sector and prompted significant trading activity as ETFs adjusted their holdings. The reclassification aimed to better reflect the global economy and address the diminishing influence of the traditional telecom sector.

title: Tech Redefined: S&P 500 Companies Worth $2.7 Trillion Change Sectors Friday
summary: Major S&P 500 companies like Facebook, Twitter, and Google are exiting the tech sector and reclassifying into a new "communication-services" sector. This shift, affecting 23 companies valued at $2.7 trillion, will cause significant trading activity as index providers rebalance their portfolios, impacting ETFs and investors. The move represents the most significant overhaul of the GICS standard since its inception in 1999.

title: Tech Redefined: S&P 500 Companies Worth $2.7 Trillion Change Sectors Friday
summary: Twenty-three S&P 500 companies, including Facebook, Twitter, and Google, valued at a combined $2.7 trillion, are being reclassified out of the tech sector into a new 'communication-services' sector. This significant overhaul, marking the biggest change to the Global Industry Classification Standard since 1999, is expected to trigger over $20 billion in stock trades as ETFs and investors realign their portfolios. Despite the large-scale reshuffling coinciding with "quad witching," market participants anticipate limited volatility due to ample preparation time.

title: Amazon to Launch 8 New Alexa-Powered Devices: Report
summary: Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) is reportedly planning to launch at least eight new Alexa-powered smart home devices, including a voice-controlled microwave oven, an amplifier, and an in-car gadget. This expansion is expected to intensify competition with rivals like Apple, Alphabet, and Microsoft in the smart speaker market, and marks Amazon's significant entry into the home appliance space. The move aligns with CEO Jeff Bezos's vision of integrating Alexa more deeply into everyday life, further expanding Amazon's presence in the smart home ecosystem.

title: Google denies bias after video shows Sergey Brin ‘upset’ over Trump’s election
summary: Google denied political bias after an internal video from 2016 surfaced showing co-founder Sergey Brin expressing disappointment over Donald Trump's election. The company stated that the video reflected employees' personal views and asserted that political bias never influences its products. This comes amidst increasing accusations from conservative politicians and activists about Google's alleged promotion of negative news about Trump.

title: Why Snapchat's Trainwreck Stock Will Never Have A Facebook Rebound
summary: This article argues that Snap Inc. (SNAP) will not experience a rebound similar to Facebook (FB) due to its dual-class share structure, which grants co-founders control over 96% of voting rights, leaving public investors with no recourse. The author criticizes CEO Evan Spiegel's leadership, poor company performance, and lagging margins compared to competitors. Despite a significant stock price drop, SNAP is still considered overvalued given its financial struggles and intense competition from Facebook's various platforms.

title: Simulators Provide Virtual Scenarios for Real-World Autonomous Driving
summary: The article discusses how self-driving car companies are utilizing simulation software to test autonomous vehicles in virtual environments, significantly reducing the risks and costs associated with real-world testing. Applied Intuition, a startup co-founded by Peter Ludwig, sells this software, allowing companies to expose robot cars to countless scenarios without danger. This approach helps companies, particularly those without the resources of giants like Waymo, accelerate the development and safety validation of autonomous driving technology.

title: Sonos gets IFTTT support: Here are the new things your smart speakers can now do
summary: Sonos smart speakers now integrate with IFTTT, allowing them to be part of automated smart home routines. This integration enables features like music pausing during phone calls or doorbell rings, and starting/stopping music based on user location. Sonos is positioning itself as a platform-agnostic company, working with various smart home ecosystems.

title: Gartner Hype Cycle for Data Management Positions Three Technologies in the Innovation Trigger Phase in 2018
summary: Gartner's 2018 Hype Cycle for Data Management identifies DataOps, private cloud database platform as a service (dbPaaS), and machine learning (ML)-enabled data management as entering the Innovation Trigger phase. This indicates these technologies are generating significant interest, with a strong focus on execution and cloud-first delivery models in the data management space. The report highlights that while DataOps and ML-enabled data management are in nascent stages, dbPaaS is rapidly approaching mainstream adoption, especially for organizations with specific security or regulatory needs.

title: Vertical Aerospace makes ‘flying cars’ with more grounded aspirations
summary: Vertical Aerospace, a UK-based startup, is developing electric vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) aircraft with plans to launch a piloted "air taxi" service by 2022. Unlike many competitors focusing on autonomous flight, Vertical Aerospace is pursuing a more realistic approach by integrating existing aviation regulations and utilizing technologies from Formula 1 racing. The company's demonstrator aircraft has already flown, and they are working with aviation authorities to certify their models, aiming for a commercially viable service within four years.

title: Mobile Native Advertising – How to Boost Signups (and Revenue!) for Your Mobile App
summary: This article discusses how mobile native advertising can help boost app signups and revenue. It highlights five key reasons for its effectiveness: combating banner blindness, facilitating user discovery, enabling compelling storytelling, precise audience targeting, and the use of native video ads. The article uses Blinkist as a case study to demonstrate the success of native advertising on the Outbrain platform.

title: BlackRock voted to replace Tesla's Musk with independent chairman
summary: BlackRock Inc. funds voted in favor of a shareholder proposal to replace Elon Musk with an independent chairman at Tesla Inc., a move not previously reported. The proposal, aimed at improving corporate oversight by splitting the chairman and CEO roles, was ultimately defeated at Tesla's shareholder meeting in June. BlackRock, a top-10 Tesla stockholder, stated its decision was driven by fiduciary duties to clients and a commitment to drive long-term shareholder value.

title: Which Companies Have The Highest Gross Profit Per Employee?
summary: This article ranks S&P 500 companies by Gross Profit Per Employee (GPPE) for 2017 to assess human capital efficiency after product costs. It highlights that the Energy sector has the highest GPPE, with Financial and Healthcare companies also performing strongly. The analysis also notes an improved ranking for Technology companies like Facebook and Apple in GPPE compared to Revenue Per Employee, due to their high gross margins.

title: Netflix Snaps Up Indian Drama ‘Garbage,’ Hoping to Expand Its International Reach
summary: Netflix has acquired the worldwide streaming rights to the Indian drama 'Garbage', a move seen as part of its strategy to expand into the Indian market. This acquisition follows recent underwhelming subscriber growth, especially internationally, and reflects Netflix's intention to adapt its offerings and potentially its pricing structure to appeal to the significant untapped potential in India. The film, directed by Q, is expected to help Netflix reach new audiences in the region.

title: The little live-TV streaming service that could
summary: FuboTV, a live-TV streaming service without a legacy business, faces intense competition from media giants but differentiates itself through agility and innovation, such as 4K HDR support and dynamic ad insertion. Initially focused on soccer and international programming, FuboTV pivoted to offer a broader cable TV bundle, aiming for significant growth despite not disclosing current subscriber numbers. The company's strategy involves rapid product improvement, targeted digital ad campaigns to acquire subscribers cheaply, and seeking further funding to expand internationally.

title: TransUnion Nabs MediaLink’s Matt Spiegel To Grow Its Digital Media Footprint
summary: TransUnion has hired Matt Spiegel, former MediaLink executive and digital ad veteran, as EVP of digital marketing solutions to expand its digital media footprint. Spiegel will focus on developing digital marketing products across TransUnion's verticals, entering the broader media industry, and strengthening the company's identity strategy, leveraging its extensive consumer data. This move aims to substantially grow the digital marketing solutions group, which saw a 21% revenue increase in the second quarter to $55 million.

title: Technology stocks make up too much of the S&P 500, so the index has a big move planned for Google, Facebook
summary: The S&P 500 is planning a significant reclassification, moving heavyweight tech companies like Alphabet and Facebook into a new Communication Services sector. This move addresses concerns about technology stocks' outsized component in the index, which currently stands at 26 percent. The reclassification will lead to changes in sector weightings and potential shifts in investment vehicles tracking these sectors.

title: Speaker maker Sonos goes public, but acknowledges vulnerability
summary: Speaker maker Sonos Inc. went public with its stock surging 33% above its IPO price, achieving an implied market value of $1.95bn. Despite a successful market debut, the company acknowledges a vulnerability stemming from its reliance on tech giants like Amazon, Apple, and Google, who could potentially enter the hardware market or alter their integration terms, impacting Sonos's future profitability.

title: Is Apple now too big to fail?
summary: This article discusses Apple Inc. reaching a $1 trillion valuation, highlighting the immense power accumulated by a few tech giants and the lack of scrutiny they face. It draws parallels to the "too big to fail" concept from the banking crisis, arguing that the collapse of these tech companies would have disastrous economic and social consequences. The author urges for greater accountability through legal and economic means.

title: How Apple got to $1T market value
summary: Apple Inc. became the first U.S.-based company with a market value of $1 trillion, four decades after its inception. The article details Apple's journey from its co-founding by Steve Jobs to its current status as a tech giant, highlighting key products like the iPod and iPhone, Jobs's return to save the company, and Tim Cook's leadership in expanding its market value and business strategies. It also touches on future challenges and opportunities for Apple, particularly concerning the iPhone and new services.

title: You can now buy stock in a browser: Opera just raised $115 million in an IPO
summary: Opera, the underdog browser company, successfully raised $115 million in an initial public offering, selling 9.6 million American depositary shares at $12 each. The stock rose 10 percent on Friday, and the company also secured an additional $60 million in private funding. Opera plans to use these funds for acquisitions and expanding its news service and app globally, leveraging its increased financial success attributed to its AI-powered news offerings.

title: Amazon’s Profit Soars to Record
summary: Amazon.com Inc. reported its profit topped $2 billion for the first time, driven by its newer services businesses like cloud computing, advertising, and seller services. This marks three consecutive quarters of over $1 billion in profits and extends its profitability streak over three years. While these high-margin areas offset its traditional lower-margin retail business, Amazon's profits are still smaller than other tech giants like Alphabet and Microsoft.

title: Penn announces online master's degree on Coursera platform
summary: The University of Pennsylvania has partnered with Coursera to launch its first fully online master's degree in computer and information technology, aimed at working adults seeking career changes. This Ivy League degree offers a significantly reduced tuition of $26,300 compared to the on-campus version, making elite education more accessible. The program emphasizes rigor, selective admissions, and flexibility for nontraditional students, with graduates receiving full Penn alumni status.

title: Amazon Rivalry at Core of Partnership With Walmart: Microsoft CEO
summary: Walmart and Microsoft have formed a five-year partnership centered around Microsoft's cloud solutions and AI technologies to directly compete with Amazon. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella explicitly stated that their shared rivalry with Amazon is "absolutely core" to this collaboration. Walmart aims to leverage Microsoft's innovations to enhance its online sales platform and customer experience.

title: Self-Driving Startup Pony.ai Secures $214 Million Since January
summary: Self-driving startup Pony.ai, founded by former Baidu and Google veterans, has secured $214 million in funding within its first six months of operation in 2018. The capital will be used to expand its autonomous vehicle fleet, increase headcount, and accelerate market entry. The company's recent funding rounds highlight growing investor confidence in its team, technology, and commercialization path, as China races to develop its self-driving car sector with new national regulations.

title: ETF of the Week: Communication Services Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLC)
summary: The article discusses the Communication Services Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLC), the first ETF dedicated to the new communication services sector. Launched to align with GICS reclassification, XLC provides exposure to companies from media, retailing, and software & services industries, including major "FANG" stocks. It also covers the implications for existing SPDR sector ETFs like XLY and XLK due to these reclassifications.

title: Uber will rent scooters through its app in partnership with Lime
summary: Uber is investing in electric scooter rental company Lime as part of a $335 million financing round, valuing Lime at $1.1 billion. The partnership will see Uber promote Lime within its app and brand some scooters with its logo, a move that parallels its acquisition and expansion of electric bike service Jump. This alliance comes amid a growing "scooter ground war" and reflects Uber's strategy to expand its app into a central platform for various urban transportation options.

title: Ad giant IPG bets big on consumer data with $2.3 billion Acxiom deal
summary: Interpublic Group (IPG) is acquiring Acxiom’s Marketing Solutions business unit for $2.3 billion to enhance its data capabilities and reduce reliance on digital ad giants like Facebook and Google. This deal aims to provide IPG agencies with anonymized customer data for more relevant and targeted advertising. The move also signals IPG's strategy to help clients navigate the evolving digital advertising landscape and address concerns around data ethics and privacy in a post-Cambridge Analytica world.

title: Browser maker Opera has filed to go public
summary: Norway-based company Opera Ltd. has filed for an initial public offering in the U.S., aiming to raise up to $115 million. The company reported $128.9 million in operating revenue and a net income of $6.1 million in 2017. Opera, which manages a web browser for desktop and mobile, generates revenue primarily through deals with search engines like Google and Yandex, and will be listed on NASDAQ under the symbol OPRA.

title: Calico and AbbVie Add $1 Billion to Anti-Aging Joint Venture
summary: AbbVie Inc. and Google-backed Calico Life Sciences LLC have committed an additional $1 billion to their joint venture focused on discovering new treatments for age-related diseases like neurodegeneration and cancer. This investment builds upon the initial $1.5 billion provided in 2014, with Calico leading discovery research and AbbVie responsible for clinical trials and commercialization.

title: AT&T to buy online ad exchange firm AppNexus
summary: AT&T Inc. announced its acquisition of online advertisement exchange company AppNexus Inc., less than a month after closing its $85 billion Time Warner Inc. deal. This acquisition aims to expand AT&T's online advertising capabilities to better compete with Alphabet Inc.'s Google and Facebook Inc., allowing them to sell targeted ads for networks like TNT and CNN. The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter of 2018.

title: DroneDeploy and Cloudflare Workers
summary: This article details how DroneDeploy leverages Cloudflare Workers to enhance its drone imagery platform. By pushing authentication to the edge and using Workers to build custom signed URLs, DroneDeploy maintains architectural flexibility across multiple cloud providers and ensures secure delivery of thousands of image tiles to users operating in variable network conditions. The solution allows for advanced edge authentication and prepares for future optimizations using Cloudflare's caching capabilities.

title: Why Did Google Remove Uber Booking From Maps?
summary: Google has quietly removed the ability to book Uber rides directly from its Google Maps app on Android. While users can still see price ranges for ride-hailing services, they must now open the Uber app separately to book a ride. This move follows a similar removal of the feature from Google Maps on iOS last summer, effectively demoting Uber's integrated status to that of other ride-hailing competitors.

title: Kevin O'Leary's OGIG: Best New Tech ETF?
summary: Kevin O’Leary's O’Shares Global Internet Giants ETF (OGIG), launched on June 5, aims to provide investors with exposure to large global internet and e-commerce companies demonstrating quality and growth potential. The rules-based ETF includes a diverse portfolio of companies, some of which O'Leary notes are experiencing faster growth than well-known giants like Amazon. The article lists OGIG's top 10 holdings as of June 15, 2018.

title: Google Invests $550 Million in Chinese Online Shopping Site JD.com
summary: Google is investing $550 million in Chinese online retailer JD.com, deepening its ties with China and intensifying its rivalry with Amazon. This partnership will help both companies expand their retailing presence, with JD.com selling products on Google Shopping to reach consumers in the U.S. and Europe, diversifying beyond China's competitive e-commerce market.

title: Apple to Netflix: We see your two Obamas and raise you an Oprah
summary: Apple has signed a multi-year content partnership deal with Oprah Winfrey, marking a significant move for the tech giant's media ambitions. This deal follows similar efforts by other tech companies like Netflix and Facebook to secure top talent and original programming. Oprah will create original content for Apple's upcoming platform while remaining CEO of OWN, showcasing the increasing competition for content among tech companies.

title: More startups turning software vendors for large enterprises: IBM's Seema Kumar
summary: IBM's Seema Kumar highlights a growing trend of startups becoming independent software vendors (ISVs) for large enterprises, a strategy IBM, Google, and Microsoft are actively pursuing to leverage emerging technologies. Kumar emphasizes the importance of partnering with ISVs to access a large customer base and empower developers within enterprises. IBM's Global Entrepreneurship Programme has supported over 1,200 startups in India by providing technology aid, mentoring, and introductions to its extensive customer network.

title: 12 American Companies That Control Tech
summary: This article lists and details the 12 American companies that dominate the tech sector, focusing on their market capitalization, revenue, net income, and number of employees as of May 2018. It highlights the race among top tech companies to reach a $1 trillion valuation and discusses how many of these giants established their market positions by creating innovative, industry-standard products. The analysis also touches on their current strategies and future outlook, particularly regarding emerging technologies like AI, blockchain, and autonomous driving.

title: What’s Changed: 2018 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Full Life Cycle API Management
summary: Gartner's 2018 Magic Quadrant for Full Life Cycle API Management evaluates 22 providers based on their ability to execute and completeness of vision. The report highlights a shift towards APIs being used for external business channels and partner integrations, with new entrants like Amazon Web Services and Microsoft. Google (Apigee) and CA Technologies led the rankings, while IBM, Software AG, MuleSoft, TIBCO Software, and Red Hat remained leaders.

title: Palo Alto Networks picks up star Google, SoftBank executive as CEO
summary: Palo Alto Networks has named former Google and SoftBank executive Nikesh Arora as its new CEO. This move is seen as a significant win for the $19 billion cybersecurity company, which has experienced a 49 percent stock jump over the past year, signaling potential for further growth.

title: What to Expect of Google and Softbank Star Nikesh Arora, Palo Alto Network’s New CEO
summary: Nikesh Arora, former Google and Softbank executive, is set to become the new CEO of Palo Alto Networks on June 6th.
