Despite lacking cybersecurity experience, Arora is known for his ability to build corporate behemoths and institute financial discipline, which investors hope he will apply to Palo Alto Networks to shore up finances and continue its growth as a platform player in cloud security. The announcement of his appointment has already led to a more than 3% rise in Palo Alto Networks' share price in after-hours trading.

title: Former Google and SoftBank executive joins Palo Alto Networks as CEO
summary: Nikesh Arora, a former executive at both SoftBank and Google, has been appointed as the new CEO and chairman of Palo Alto Networks. He was previously slated to become CEO of SoftBank but resigned due to a disagreement over succession timing. Mark McLaughlin, the current CEO, will transition to vice chairman of the board.

title: Short Seller Goes Long on Snap Stock
summary: Notorious short seller Andrew Left of Citron Research has gone long on Snap Inc (SNAP) stock, arguing that the market's extreme negativity and high short interest create a compelling bullish case. Despite a 45% year-to-date decline due to app redesign issues and negative celebrity reviews, Left believes even a lack of further bad news could be a catalyst. He suggests Snap is undervalued compared to peers like Facebook regarding daily active users and could be a buyout target for companies like Alphabet or Apple.

title: Sector Watch: Good times for American growth
summary: Despite trade tensions, rising interest rates, and stock market volatility, U.S. stocks are showing continued optimism driven by strong economic growth, lower taxes, and declining unemployment. Fund managers Tony Genua of AGF Investments Inc. and Noah Blackstein of 1832 Asset Management LP are identifying investment opportunities in innovative companies across technology, financial services, and healthcare sectors, focusing on high-growth potential and sustainable expansion. Both managers emphasize active portfolio management and selective stock-picking, with a focus on market leaders and disruptive technologies while managing risk through diversification and profit-taking.

title: CEO Pay Ratio: A Deep Data Dive
summary: This article provides a deep dive into CEO pay ratio data, which became available after the SEC mandated disclosure for fiscal years beginning on or after January 1, 2017. It analyzes trends across Russell 3000 and Equilar 500 companies, examining how ratios vary by company size, market capitalization, industry, and the disclosure design choices companies made. The analysis highlights significant disparities, outlier cases, and the methodologies companies used to calculate and report their CEO pay ratios.
source: The Harvard Law School Forum on Corporate Governance
source_domain: The Harvard Law School Forum on Corporate Governance

title: These tech companies have the most stressed-out workers
summary: A survey by workplace app Blind revealed that 70.73% of Credit Karma employees suffer from job burnout, making it the highest among tech companies surveyed. Other companies with over 50% burnout rates include Expedia, Oracle, and Lyft, while Netflix had the lowest at 38.89%. The article highlights the significant impact of burnout, with a separate survey indicating it's responsible for nearly half of staff turnover in the U.S.

title: Microsoft is now more valuable than Alphabet — by about $10 billion
summary: Microsoft has surpassed Alphabet in market capitalization, becoming the world's third most valuable company. This shift occurred as Microsoft's market value reached $749 billion compared to Alphabet's $739 billion, largely driven by significant growth in Microsoft's cloud computing business. Microsoft's stock surged 40 percent over the past 12 months, greatly outpacing Alphabet's gains.

title: How David Cheriton Beats Everyone at Tech Investing
summary: David Cheriton, a Stanford University computer science professor, has an exceptional track record as an early investor and founder of successful tech startups like Google, VMware, and Arista Networks. His success stems from a combination of luck—being at Stanford and meeting brilliant people—and a focused approach of investing time and money only in companies where he can add significant technical value. Cheriton emphasizes seeking opportunities with real value, multiple reasons for success, and not necessarily being the first mover, treating each investment as a "baby" rather than just a bet.

title: George Soros' fund bought $35 million of Tesla bonds while loading up on Amazon, Netflix stock
summary: George Soros' investment firm, Soros Fund Management, purchased $35 million worth of Tesla convertible bonds in the first quarter of 2018, providing significant backing to the troubled electric carmaker. The fund also made substantial investments in Amazon and Netflix stock, acquiring 51,200 shares of Amazon and 148,500 shares of Netflix, while simultaneously divesting its holdings in Twitter. These moves offer insight into Soros Fund Management's investment strategy during a period of market volatility for some tech giants.

title: 3 Great Dividend-Growth Funds
summary: This article highlights three dividend-growth funds recommended by Morningstar analysts, focusing on their investment strategies and key characteristics. It features Hartford Dividend and Growth A (IHGIX), T. Rowe Price Dividend Growth (PRDGX), and Vanguard Dividend Appreciation Fund, discussing their management approaches, risk profiles, and performance in various market conditions. The funds are presented as excellent core holdings for investors seeking companies with a history of increasing dividends.

title: Malicious Chrome extensions infect 100,000-plus users, again
summary: Over two months, seven malicious Chrome extensions stole login credentials and installed cryptocurrency miners, infecting more than 100,000 users. These extensions, hosted in Google's official Chrome Web Store, executed JavaScript to create botnets, steal credentials, and mine digital coins. Despite Google's efforts to remove them, the regular success of such attacks suggests the problem of malicious extensions will continue.

title: With .app, Google plans to build a safer Web - The Parallax
summary: Google is launching the new .app top-level domain, which aims to enhance web security by mandating HTTPS encryption for all websites using it. This initiative, which Google acquired for $25 million in 2015, makes it the first TLD to enforce HTTPS by default, helping to protect user data from interception and spoofing. While seen as a significant step towards a more secure internet, critics note it isn't a complete solution against all forms of cyber threats.

title: Health Care Information System Market:-Technological Health
summary: Orian Research has published a report on the Health Care Information System Market, detailing its current standing, future predictions, and key players. The report provides a professional and in-depth study of the market, including definitions, classifications, applications, and industry chain structure, with a forecast extending to 2025. It identifies major manufacturers, types, applications, and regional distribution, alongside factors driving and hindering market growth.

title: NetApp Announces AFF A800, ONTAP 9.4, & New Cloud Services
summary: NetApp has announced significant updates including the new AFF A800 all-flash array, ONTAP 9.4, and new intelligent cloud services such as NetApp Cloud Volumes for Google Cloud Platform. These advancements aim to support high-performance AI and ML workloads, offering end-to-end NVMe capabilities and enhanced hybrid cloud data management. The company is also partnering with NVIDIA and Broadcom to further strengthen its offerings in AI and Fibre Channel compatibility.

title: Why We Built Toast Go® 2: The Future of the POS is in Your Hands
summary: Toast Go® 2 is introduced as the next generation handheld POS system, designed specifically for the restaurant industry to enhance speed, safety, and flexibility. The article details how this new device improves on previous models by offering features like contactless payments, extended battery life, and increased durability, ultimately aiming to boost restaurant efficiency and guest satisfaction. It highlights the positive impact of handheld POS systems on various restaurant models and provides statistics on increased revenue and efficiency.

title: Eastman touts 10th anniversary of Eastman Tritan™ copolyester at NPE
summary: Eastman is celebrating the 10th anniversary of its Eastman Tritan™ copolyester, a clear, tough, chemical-resistant polymer. Tritan is being utilized in new smart technology applications, including digital agriculture with Arable Labs, the SproutsIO smart microgarden, and Hidrate Spark smart water bottles. The company highlights Tritan's versatility and performance properties, positioning it as a key material for the Internet of Things (IoT) revolution.

title: Sherwin-Williams’ AR app takes guesswork out of choosing paint
summary: Sherwin-Williams has enhanced its ColorSnap Visualizer mobile app with an augmented reality (AR) feature called "Instant Paint." This tool allows users to virtually preview any of the company's 1,500 paint colors on their walls in real-time using a smartphone camera. The feature aims to help customers confidently select paint colors and avoid costly repainting errors, leveraging the growing trend of AR try-before-you-buy applications in home improvement and other industries.

title: Why Domino's Pizza, Advanced Micro Devices, and Alexion Pharmaceuticals Jumped Today
summary: Domino's Pizza, Advanced Micro Devices, and Alexion Pharmaceuticals all saw significant stock gains following positive financial results. Domino's reported strong revenue and comparable-restaurant sales, AMD benefited from high demand for its CPUs and GPUs, and Alexion received good news from a phase 3 study for one of its pipeline drugs. These strong performances contributed to a positive day on Wall Street, especially for the Nasdaq Composite.

title: NYSE Suspends Trading on Amazon, Google Over Data Glitch
summary: The NYSE suspended trading on five symbols, including Amazon and Google, due to a price scale coding malfunction. This glitch caused stocks priced at $1000 or higher to be incorrectly published. While trading was suspended on the NYSE, the affected stocks continued to trade on Nasdaq, NYSE Arca, and NYSE American.

title: China’s Uber for Trucks Is Said to Raise $1.9 Billion in Funding
summary: Full Truck Alliance Group, China’s largest app for Uber-like truck services, has raised $1.9 billion in funding at a $6.5 billion valuation to expand its operations. Backers include SoftBank Vision Fund, China Reform Fund, GSR Ventures, and Alphabet Inc.’s CapitalG, along with existing investors Tencent Holdings Ltd. and Sequoia Capital. The company aims to digitalize China's fractured 5 trillion yuan logistics market by streamlining truck services and boosting efficiency.

title: ‘Unpatchable’ Nvidia Tegra X-1 flaw affects Nintendo Switch and other devices
summary: A security researcher has uncovered an "unpatchable" vulnerability, dubbed Fusée Gelée, in Nvidia Corp.'s Tegra X-1 chips that affects devices like the Nintendo Switch and Google Pixel C. This flaw exploits the chip’s USB recovery mode to bypass security and run custom code, posing a significant risk as it is hardware-based and cannot be patched post-manufacture. While Nintendo may be able to detect hacked systems via software updates, the core vulnerability remains.

title: SM Energy Sees RS Rating Rise To 73
summary: SM Energy (SM) experienced an increase in its Relative Strength Rating from 69 to 73 on Tuesday. This rise indicates improved relative price strength, identifying the stock as a potential market leader based on its price action over the past 52 weeks. The Relative Strength Rating is a key metric for investors looking for top-performing stocks.

title: How 3 Brands Brought Tech to Life at Coachella
summary: At Coachella, American Express, Google, and Amazon integrated technology into their activations, transforming the festival experience. American Express used AR for exclusive merchandise, Google highlighted its Home Max and Pixel products, and Amazon offered fashion advice with the Echo Look. These brands aimed to showcase technology's impact and future role in lifestyle and entertainment.

title: JPMorgan U.S. Quality Factor ETF ETF Price, Holdings, & News (NYSEARCA:JQUA)
summary: The JPMorgan U.S. Quality Factor ETF (JQUA) is an exchange-traded fund that tracks the JP Morgan US Quality Factor index, focusing on profitability, earnings, and solvency from the Russell 1000 companies. JQUA was launched on November 8, 2017, and is managed by JPMorgan Chase, with holdings including major tech companies like Alphabet, Broadcom, and Apple. The ETF has performed well, with its stock increasing by 10.6% this year to $63.34 as of the latest data.

title: Free Qualys services give orgs visibility of their digital certs and cloud assets
summary: Qualys announced two new free services, CertView and CloudView, to help organizations gain visibility into their digital certificates and cloud assets. CertView provides continuous inventory and assessment of external-facing digital certificates, helping to mitigate risks from expired or vulnerable SSL/TLS configurations. CloudView offers topological visibility and insight into the security and compliance posture of public cloud infrastructure across major providers like AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud, facilitating asset discovery and continuous security monitoring.
